# NY To $180K: Sign Up For The 2016 Salary Increase Newsletter!
## If you prefer the pay raise news to come to you (instead of having to seek it out), sign up here!
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onJune 7, 2016 at 5:33 PM
0
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/ny-to-180k-sign-up-for-the-2016-salary-increase-newsletter/&text=NY%20To%20$180K:%20Sign%20Up%20For%20The%202016%20Salary%20Increase%20Newsletter!)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/ny-to-180k-sign-up-for-the-2016-salary-increase-newsletter/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/ny-to-180k-sign-up-for-the-2016-salary-increase-newsletter/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Back in December, we launched [Above the Law bonus alerts](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/12/where-are-the-biglaw-bonuses-associate-bonus-watch-day-2/). Thousands of readers signed up to receive real-time notifications of the latest Biglaw bonus news.

Given the heavy overlap between bonuses and salaries, we are now expanding the bonus alerts to include notifications of firms matching the [Cravath $180K scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/breaking-ny-to-180k-cravath-raises-associate-base-salaries/). Current subscribers to the bonus alerts will automatically get notified of base salary raises as well.

If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. If you didn’t sign up but would now like to receive alerts for bonus and salary news, please sign up by entering your email address below. (And if you currently get the alerts but want to stop getting them, simply click the “unsubscribe” link in an alert.)

### [ How Will Walgreens’ Expansion Into Specialty Pharmacy Affect The Industry? ](https://medcitynews.com/2024/04/walgreens-specialty-pharmacy-drugs/)
Walgreens announced that it is expanding its specialty pharmacy offerings. Experts think that this move could yield several strategic benefits, given the higher profit margins associated with specialty medications compared to traditional drugs. They also think Walgreens’ move could lead to greater competition, consolidation, and innovation within the broader pharmacy industry.
By KATIE ADAMS - MEDCITY NEWS

# Associate Bonus Watch: Skadden Seems To Be Falling In Line
## It's not a party until Skadden shows up.
By [Elie Mystal](https://abovethelaw.com/author/elie-mystal/)  
onNovember 28, 2017 at 2:00 PMNovember 28, 2017 at 1:48 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/associate-bonus-watch-skadden-seems-to-be-falling-in-line/&text=Associate%20Bonus%20Watch:%20Skadden%20Seems%20To%20Be%20Falling%20In%20Line)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/associate-bonus-watch-skadden-seems-to-be-falling-in-line/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/associate-bonus-watch-skadden-seems-to-be-falling-in-line/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Skadden, as is its tradition, is sending around individualized bonuses memos today. Our tipsters from a number of class years are reporting numbers in line with [the Cravath scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/associate-bonus-watch-cravath-announces-its-2017-associate-bonuses/).

So, if you work at Skadden, Major League rules apply: [“You don’t want to celebrate in front of a guy who just died.”](https://getyarn.io/yarn-clip/cb9813a9-aaab-4ed2-8dc0-fc462d36c051) If you received more than the Cravath scale, you are special. Congratulations on all your success. If you received less, I don’t know what to tell you. It’s not business, it’s totally personal, the firm doesn’t like you and gave you a crappy bonus.

For me, the bonus scale doesn’t get set until Skadden comes out. That’s because I’m old and [I remember 2008](https://abovethelaw.com/2008/11/associate-bonus-watch-here-comes-skadden/?rf=1). As the Great Recession was wreaking havoc on clients and eventually their law firms, Skadden came out with a bonus payment twice as high as Cravath. All the other Biglaw firms, predictably, followed the lower Cravath scale. That was a long time ago, but I always remember that Skadden at least has the capability of marching to the beat of its own drum. It doesn’t have to slavishly follow Cravath. It can do what it thinks is right.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
This year, it thinks it’s right to just follow Cravath.

That makes sense. With this year’s bonus season playing out almost exactly like last year’s, despite the fact that the stock market is exploding upwards, everything feels like we’re in a giant holding pattern. Is the economy really doing this well? Are we living in a Mnuchin/Cohen fueled bubble that will burst into a thousand tears if Congress actually passes this tax plan? Will it burst if Congress doesn’t pass the tax plan?

The American government has been functionally destabilized. Who can really know what the 2018 economy is going to look like. For now, the safe move from firms with financial security is to hold the line, repeat what worked last year, and wait and see what happens.

In any event, congrats to Skadden attorneys. Except for that one guy who should take his below-market bonus as an indication to update his LinkedIn profile.

As a little reminder, we love covering the Biglaw bonus season, but we need your help. Remember: as soon as your firm’s bonus memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”). We always keep our sources on bonus stories anonymous. There’s no need to send the memo using your firm email account; your personal email account is fine. Please be sure to include the memo as proof; we like to post complete bonus memos as a service to our readers. You can take a photo of the memo and attach as a picture if you are worried about metadata in a PDF or Word file. You can also text us at 646-820-8477. We look forward to hearing from you.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks!

Elie Mystal is the Executive Editor of Above the Law and the Legal Editor for [More Perfect](http://www.wnyc.org/shows/radiolabmoreperfect). He can be reached [@ElieNYC](https://twitter.com/ElieNYC?lang=en) on Twitter, or at [elie@abovethelaw.com](mailto:elie@abovethelaw.com). He will resist.

# Another Top 50 Am Law Firm Cuts Its Global Work Force
## Better to have worked and lost in Biglaw than to have never worked at all.
By [Chris Williams](https://abovethelaw.com/author/cwilliams/)  
onJune 14, 2023 at 10:50 AMJune 20, 2023 at 11:49 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/another-top-50-am-law-firm-cuts-its-global-work-force/&text=Another%20Top%2050%20Am%20Law%20Firm%20Cuts%20Its%20Global%20Work%20Force)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/another-top-50-am-law-firm-cuts-its-global-work-force/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/another-top-50-am-law-firm-cuts-its-global-work-force/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


While a little early to say that layoffs are trending, there is without question a new data point.

Reed Smith, a firm that brought in $1,417,599,000 gross revenue in 2022, putting it at No. 29 on The American Lawyer’s 2023 Am Law 100 ranking — announced that it will be cutting about 2% of its global workforce.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
According to the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/06/14/reed-smith-cuts-global-workforce-by-50-to-address-demand-slump/), the cuts have impacted around 50 employees — about 20 staff members and 30 lawyers. As bad as it is to get cut from a firm, the good news is that those impacted will not be left cut and dry. From [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/06/14/reed-smith-cuts-global-workforce-by-50-to-address-demand-slump/):

Impacted individuals at Reed Smith are being offered individualized severance benefits as well as outplacement services, according to the firm’s statement on the cuts. Severance packages for affected individuals are based on seniority, ranging from two to four months of benefits.

The firm gave the expected explanation that the layoffs are a consequence of “a reduced level of demand for legal services across the industry”, but it is worth noting that [Reed Smith was doling out layoffs even back when many other competing firms in the tier were hiring](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/biglaw-firm-eliminates-jobs-for-second-time-in-a-year/). Market instability aside, Reed remains one of the [best firms](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/01/the-first-biglaw-firm-to-offer-billable-diversity-hours-for-all-timekeepers/) to work at [when you aren’t stuck at a courthouse telling shareholders which door they’re supposed to go to](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/04/two-of-reed-smiths-finest-will-be-stuck-on-human-directional-duty/).

Best of luck to those who are being let go from Reed Smith.

He is a former boatbuilder who cannot swim, [a published author on critical race theory, philosophy, and humor](https://www.academia.edu/33296970/Lets_Be_Frank_Parrhesia_and_the_Black_Comedic_Tradition), and has a love for cycling that occasionally annoys his peers. # Quinn Emanuel Revamps Its Summer Associate Program By Bringing Back On-Campus Interviews
## Do you have what it takes to score a summer gig at the firm?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMay 30, 2018 at 12:55 PMMay 30, 2018 at 9:31 PM
10
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/quinn-emanuel-revamps-its-summer-associate-program-by-bringing-back-on-campus-interviews/&text=Quinn%20Emanuel%20Revamps%20Its%20Summer%20Associate%20Program%20By%20Bringing%20Back%20On-Campus%20Interviews)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/quinn-emanuel-revamps-its-summer-associate-program-by-bringing-back-on-campus-interviews/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/quinn-emanuel-revamps-its-summer-associate-program-by-bringing-back-on-campus-interviews/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
About three years ago, Quinn Emanuel made big waves when the firm announced that it would be [culling its traditional summer associate program](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/06/biglaw-firm-decimates-summer-associate-program/) in favor of recruiting third-year law students and federal judicial clerks. Three years before that, Quinn Emanuel made even bigger waves when the firm [stopped conducting traditional on-campus interviews](https://abovethelaw.com/2012/03/quinn-emanuel-takes-a-new-approach-to-on-campus-recruiting/) in favor of “fun, freewheeling ‘get to know you’ part[ies].”

After six years of marching to the beat of its own drum, Quinn Emanuel is changing its tune once again, but this time, instead of doing something wildly different, the firm will be doing the same thing as almost every other Biglaw firm in the country. This fall, Quinn Emanuel will be coming to a top law school near you to recruit second-year law students for summer associate positions at the firm.

Why the change of heart? Meghan Tribe of [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/05/29/quinn-emanuel-rebuilds-summer-associate-program-with-on-campus-recruiting/) has the scoop:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
“We found that somebody who’s a 3L in law school is probably a bit closer to [identifying litigation as their area of focus] than 2Ls, and certainly people who have already completed federal clerkships are there already,” said Jennifer Barrett, administrative partner of Quinn Emanuel’s New York office.

“But with that being said, we did re-evaluate, and we recognize that there are really fantastic second-year law students who do know that they want to focus on litigation, and we certainly don’t want to leave those people on the table,” Barrett said.

Last year, Quinn Emanuel had six summer associates, this year, the firm has 20 summer associates, and according to Barrett, next year, the firm hopes to hire two or three times as many summer associates as are in this year’s class. Quinn Emanuel will be heading to 19 law schools in an effort to recruit 40 to 60 summer associates.

Do you have what it takes to score a summer gig at Quinn Emanuel? You’ll find out this fall. Best of luck, and make sure you wear your finest [flip-flops](https://abovethelaw.com/2011/08/summer-is-ending-but-flip-flops-are-still-hot-at-quinn-emanuel/).

[Quinn Emanuel Rebuilds Summer Associate Program With On-Campus Recruiting](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/05/29/quinn-emanuel-rebuilds-summer-associate-program-with-on-campus-recruiting/) [American Lawyer]

# The Biggest Biglaw Firms With The Most Women Lawyers (2023)
## An important ranking to show which firms are helping women achieve successful careers in the law.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 21, 2023 at 11:48 AMJune 22, 2023 at 10:00 AM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/the-biggest-biglaw-firms-with-the-most-women-lawyers-2023/&text=The%20Biggest%20Biglaw%20Firms%20With%20The%20Most%20Women%20Lawyers%20(2023))[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/the-biggest-biglaw-firms-with-the-most-women-lawyers-2023/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/the-biggest-biglaw-firms-with-the-most-women-lawyers-2023/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Yesterday, thanks to the recently released [National Law Journal 500 ranking](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/the-500-largest-law-firms-in-america-2023/), we found out which U.S.-centric Biglaw firms were the biggest of them all in terms of headcount. As a companion piece to the NLJ 500, we’ll now delve into the NLJ Women’s Scorecard, a ranking of the percentage of female attorneys and percentage of female partners at the largest 350 firms in the country.

For the purposes of this ranking, equity and nonequity partners were counted as partners, with staffing counts based on a firm’s average number of full-time equivalent attorneys in 2022. Temporary and contract attorneys aren’t included in the count. For a tie, the higher rank is awarded to the firm with more female equity partners.

As noted by the [National Law Journal](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2023/06/20/women-attorneys-defining-purpose-balance-and-flexibility/), women did well in law firms in 2022:

Looking at the responding firms as a group, women comprised nearly 40% of all the 151,000 attorneys included in the report. Women made up almost 24% of 34,300 equity partners, about 27% of 61,718 total partners, and nearly 50% of 72,444 associates.

Compared to the previous year’s report, the group increased female attorney representation about 1%, while female equity partner representation increased 1.1%, female partner representation rose 0.8%, and female associate representation ticked up 0.7%.

“There is a ton of momentum given the number of women graduating from law school, yet a lot of firms still have room to grow and create an environment that is conducive to women having a work-life balance that allows them to have robust careers and families,” [Nicole Dawson, chief people officer of Berry Appleman & Leiden,] said.

Without further ado, here is the NLJ Women’s Scorecard Top 10 for 2023:

- Berry Appleman & Leiden
- Fragomen
- Kubicki Draper
- Kaufman Borgeest & Ryan
- Cole Scott & Kissane
- Littler Mendelson
- Manning Gross + Massenburg
- Kelley Kronenberg
- Wood Smith Henning & Berman
- Constangy Brooks Smith & Prophete
You may be wondering where the largest, namebrand Biglaw firms appear on this list. While the majority of the top 30 firms on the scorecard have a headcount of about 300 or less, there were some exceptions, with Fragomen, Littler, Ogletree, Jackson Lewis, Cooley, Willkie Farr, Ropes & Gray, Lewis Brisbois, and Davis Wright Tremaine,  all making an appearance.

Congratulations to all of the firms that succeeded in boosting their ranks in this year’s Women’s Scorecard by placing women in leadership roles and fostering a pipeline of female and diverse attorneys.

You can check out the rest of the rankings [here](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2023/06/20/the-2023-nlj-500-women-in-law-scorecard/).

[The NLJ 500: Women in Law Scorecard](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2023/06/20/the-2023-nlj-500-women-in-law-scorecard/) [National Law Journal]
[Women Attorneys Defining Purpose, Balance and Flexibility](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2023/06/20/women-attorneys-defining-purpose-balance-and-flexibility/) [National Law Journal]

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# Yet Another Biglaw Firm Matches Cravath, And Associates Are Thrilled
## 'It's a miracle,' said one associate.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 25, 2022 at 2:32 PMMarch 25, 2022 at 1:37 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/baker-botts-raise-2022/&text=Yet%20Another%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Matches%20Cravath,%20And%20Associates%20Are%20Thrilled)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/baker-botts-raise-2022/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/baker-botts-raise-2022/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Associates at some firms are getting pretty anxious. Almost everyone else has heard about raises. What could the hold-up possibly be? Don’t worry,  your raise (of some sort) is probably on the way, so just keep waiting patiently… if you think you can, that is.

Speaking of raises, it looks like Baker Botts, a firm that came in at No. 64 in the most recent Am Law 100, has finally decided to weigh in during the latest round of salary wars. What’ll it be? It’s a Cravath match! “It’s a miracle,” said one source who apparently thought this day would never come.

This is what the new salary scale looks like at Baker Botts:



These salary hikes are retroactive not to January 1, but March 1, and associates are pretty ticked off about it. Nonetheless, congrats to everyone at the firm.

(Flip to the next page to see the memo from Baker Botts.)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of this stuff. So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches%20Cravath) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches Cravath”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we’ll also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# Will More Biglaw Firms Follow Dentons And Leave China?
## Dentons may be the first Western firm to fall.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onAugust 9, 2023 at 5:17 PMAugust 9, 2023 at 2:41 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/will-more-biglaw-firms-follow-dentons-and-leave-china/&text=Will%20More%20Biglaw%20Firms%20Follow%20Dentons%20And%20Leave%20China?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/will-more-biglaw-firms-follow-dentons-and-leave-china/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/will-more-biglaw-firms-follow-dentons-and-leave-china/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

Dentons is not the first professional services firm practicing law to pull out of China. It is not going to be the last. Given the conditions, which make it virtually impossible to practice there as a Western firm and comply with the laws and regulations, it wouldn’t be unsurprising if other firms follow suit.

— Kent Zimmermann, a U.S.-based principal at Zeughauser Group, in comments given to the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/international-edition/2023/08/08/will-dentons-china-breakup-trigger-a-domino-effect/), concerning Dentons’ withdrawal from its combination with Dacheng in China due to [government regulatory issues](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/dentons-dacheng-break-up/). “The solution may be exactly what Dentons is doing—to have an independent Chinese firm with which the Western firm has a close relationship, but they’re independent entities,” he said.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) and [Threads](https://www.threads.net/@stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

####Topics
[Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/biglaw/), [China](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/china/), [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/)

# Partners Forced Out As Biglaw Firm Considers Strategic Shift, It's Reportedly A 'Bloodbath Over There'
## These partners are being shown the Brexit.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onSeptember 11, 2018 at 2:35 PMSeptember 11, 2018 at 10:06 PM
14
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/09/partners-forced-out-as-biglaw-firm-considers-strategic-shift-its-reportedly-a-bloodbath-over-there/&text=Partners%20Forced%20Out%20As%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Considers%20Strategic%20Shift,%20It’s%20Reportedly%20A%20‘Bloodbath%20Over%20There’)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/09/partners-forced-out-as-biglaw-firm-considers-strategic-shift-its-reportedly-a-bloodbath-over-there/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/09/partners-forced-out-as-biglaw-firm-considers-strategic-shift-its-reportedly-a-bloodbath-over-there/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Four partners in the London office of Ropes & Gray are being forced out following a strategic shift in the firm’s direction.

This is according to a [report](https://www.legalweek.com/2018/09/11/four-partners-to-leave-ropes-in-london-as-firm-rethinks-city-focus/) from Legal Week — where they use the delightful euphemism “managed exit” to describe the move — which says the downsizing will come from the firm’s real estate and restructuring-related teams, and the partners will formally depart from the Biglaw firm over the next several months:

Multiple sources have told Legal Week that the quartet are set to leave following discussions with firmwide management, who travelled into London last week from the US.

All four partners, who Legal Week has decided not to name, work across the firm’s restructuring-related and real estate groups. It is understood they met with management on Friday (7 September) and are expected to leave over the coming months.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)

### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
This is in addition to the planned retirement of  international real estate investments and transactions group partner, Iain Morpeth, who will depart the firm at the end of the year.

This new focus for the firm has left some knowledgable about the situation concerned:

One former partner said of the exits: “It seems like a bit of a bloodbath over there at the moment. It has for a long time. The last two years have been shaky.”

Wondering exactly what has been going on at the firm? Well, the London office of Ropes has seen its fair share of notable departures over that time frame, including former office co-founder Maurice Allen, investment funds partners Monica Gogna and Anand Damodaran (they went to Dechert and Kirkland & Ellis, respectively), finance partners Mark Wesseldine and Fergus Wheeler (who joined King & Spalding), and a 100-person patent prosecution team (which became Haley Guiliano).

From Pilot and Above The Law  
As also noted by Legal Week, the partner compensation system at the firm is designed as a black box, which assists the firm in carefully discarding partners without formally asking them to leave:

Ropes has previously faced criticism from ex-partners about its black box remuneration system, which makes it relatively easy for management to encourage people towards the door by docking pay in their annual review without actively asking them to leave.

Last year, Ropes enjoyed a 7.5 percent increase in total firm revenue, and the London office enjoyed its most successful year to date.

# Piping Hot New Bonuses, Fresh From The Biglaw Oven
## Associates have their cake and eat it too.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onDecember 2, 2022 at 11:35 AMDecember 2, 2022 at 12:02 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/bonuses-2022-baker-botts/&text=Piping%20Hot%20New%20Bonuses,%20Fresh%20From%20The%20Biglaw%20Oven)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/bonuses-2022-baker-botts/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/bonuses-2022-baker-botts/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
I was about to open this post with a butcher and candlemaker joke and then realized that’s how I kicked off [last year’s](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/baker-botts-raises-21/) Baker Botts announcement. There really are only so many cheesy jokes to make.

Anyway, nothing says lovin’ like bonuses from the oven (oh jeez, that’s the joke I made [for Pillsbury in 2016](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/nothin-says-lovin-like-180k-in-your-paycheck/)). Let’s just power through this… the firm ranks 65th in the Am Law 100 and grossed $723,228,000 in 2021.

Here are the numbers for associates and special counsel working in the US offices:



These will be payable on December 31. Those outside the US will hear individually about bonuses.

Congrats.

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of this stuff. So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches%20) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we’ll also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

[Joe Patrice](http://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/) is a senior editor at Above the Law and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](http://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). Feel free to [email](mailto:joepatrice@abovethelaw.com) any tips, questions, or comments. Follow him on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/josephpatrice) if you’re interested in law, politics, and a healthy dose of college sports news. Joe also serves as a [Managing Director at RPN Executive Search](https://www.rpnexecsearch.com/josephpatrice).

# Morning Docket: 10.18.18
## * Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke is the subject of no fewer than 14 separate corruption investigations. So he fired the inspector general managing the probes and replaced him with a political appointee. [[Outside](https://www.outsideonline.com/2355936/zinke-fires-inspector-general)] * Meanwhile, a Treasury official who blew the whistle on actual criminal activity was arrested. Good to see we've got our priorities straight. [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/newyork/articles/1093140/fincen-staffer-arrested-for-buzzfeed-russia-probe-leaks)] * While we've been talking about global firms invading the Houston market, V&E is looking to expand to New York, DC, and London. [[Texas Lawyer](https://www.law.com/2018/10/17/ve-targeting-new-york-dc-london-for-expansion/)] * Former West Virginia Supreme Court justice found guilty. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/2018/10/17/suspended-west-virginia-justice-convicted-in-criminal-fraud-trial/)] * Why are all the bigots going into baking? [[Courthouse News Service](https://www.courthousenews.com/discrimination-case-reopened-against-christian-bakery-owner/)] * White & Case has a plan to grow like gangbusters over the next two years. Meghan Tribe talks with the firm about this vision. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/10/17/white-case-makes-its-case-for-audacious-growth-plan/)]
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onOctober 18, 2018 at 8:24 AMOctober 18, 2018 at 5:32 AM

# Trump May Be Gone, But His Trade War Isn’t
## Many businesses have already altered their supply chains, and slugging it out on trade for several years with China did not create fertile ground for cooperation.
By [Jonathan Wolf](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jwolf/)  
onJune 29, 2021 at 3:03 PMJune 29, 2021 at 2:31 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/trump-may-be-gone-but-his-trade-war-isnt/&text=Trump%20May%20Be%20Gone,%20But%20His%20Trade%20War%20Isn’t)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/trump-may-be-gone-but-his-trade-war-isnt/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/trump-may-be-gone-but-his-trade-war-isnt/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Most economists do not believe that blunt protectionist trade policies stand to ultimately benefit American workers and American businesses.

But that certainly didn’t stop Donald Trump’s administration [from implementing an escalating series of tariffs against China](https://www.forbes.com/sites/stuartanderson/2021/05/20/trumps-tariffs-were-much-more-damaging-than-thought/?sh=42303f0565bd).

In January of 2018, the Trump administration imposed tariffs on imported solar panels and washing machines, and the next month it also announced new steel and aluminum tariffs.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
The trade war swiftly escalated in March of 2018, with China announcing its own set of tariffs on 128 U.S. exports. May of 2018 saw the Trump White House announcing additional tariffs, and China again retaliated in June of 2018 with more tariffs of its own.

This pattern of increasingly ratcheted up retaliatory tariffs continued for months.

Some of the tariffs indeed benefited workers in some sectors. But benefits for these few came at the expense of many others.

For instance, [the trade war cost U.S. consumers about $817,000 in higher prices for each job created in the washing machine industry](https://www.brookings.edu/policy2020/votervital/did-trumps-tariffs-benefit-american-workers-and-national-security/), according to one study; in the steel industry, each job created by the tariffs cost American consumers $900,000. Spending nearly seven figures to create a job with a five-figure salary is hardly good economics.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)

Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)

### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Another recent study [found that Trump’s U.S.-China trade policies ultimately cost the American economy close to a quarter of a million jobs](https://carnegieendowment.org/chinafinancialmarkets/83746). The Congressional Budget Office concluded that the trade barriers imposed by the Trump administration since January of 2018 [reduced average real household income by $580 in 2020](https://www.cbo.gov/publication/55576), in addition to shrinking the U.S. GDP by nearly a third of a percent.

Of course, [despite his many claims to the contrary](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2021/06/27/barr-describes-rift-trump-rift-over-election-fraud-claim-interviews/5365066001/), Donald Trump lost the election in 2020. Joe Biden is now the president. Given the deleterious effect the Trump tariffs had on the U.S. economy, they would seem to be destined for Uncle Joe’s growing policy scrap pile as he cleans house.

But undoing years of trade conflict isn’t as simple as stopping construction on a wall that Mexico definitely did not pay for. Many businesses have already altered their supply chains, and slugging it out on trade for several years with China did not create fertile ground for cooperation. [Most of the higher tariffs implemented during Trump’s term remain in place](https://www.cnbc.com/2021/05/18/us-companies-bearing-the-brunt-of-trumps-china-tariffs-says-moodys.html).

Biden [has promised not to enter into any new international trade agreements](https://www.brookings.edu/policy2020/votervital/did-trumps-tariffs-benefit-american-workers-and-national-security/) until ushering in what he calls “major investments here at home, in our workers and our communities.” Meanwhile, though, [the Biden administration is rebuilding relationships with traditional U.S. allies](https://www.cnbc.com/2020/12/02/biden-tells-nyt-columnist-he-wont-immediately-remove-trumps-tariffs-on-china.html) in order to “develop a coherent strategy” when collectively confronting China on trade. Some nations are already paying a steep price for doubling down on their relationship with the U.S. Exports to China from Australia, for example, [dropped by $2.3 billion in 2020](https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/australia-embraces-u-s-pays-price-china-trade-war-hits-n1270458). While Covid no doubt played a role in the 2020 decrease in Australian exports to one of its biggest trading partners, the drop was also due in part to Australia’s heightening public support of the U.S. in its trade dispute with China.

International trade is complex, and there were many legitimate underlying trade concerns which led to the Trump administration’s trade war against China. Even so, most experts agree that the escalating tariffs were the wrong way to deal with U.S.-China trade tensions. The Trump tariffs cost U.S. consumers and businesses far more than they were worth in the long run.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)

Now, however, Biden is more focused on domestic issues. The trade policies his administration has pursued thus far are subtle, [like building supply chains that do not depend so heavily on Chinese links](https://foreignpolicy.com/2021/06/22/biden-semiconductors-south-korea-china-trade-war/). But given time, after rebuilding international support from traditional U.S. allies, hopefully the new administration can confront the U.S.-China trade relationship more directly. The steep tariffs implemented under the Trump administration are an economic hurdle that U.S. businesses and consumers should not have to keep contending with.

[Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/biglaw/), [Law Firm Mergers](https://abovethelaw.com/law-firm-mergers/)
# Holy Moly! An 'Incestuous' Law Firm Merger For Foley?
## This Biglaw firm might as well be marrying its law firm cousin.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onApril 26, 2017 at 12:16 PMApril 26, 2017 at 12:18 PM
16
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/04/holy-moly-an-incestuous-law-firm-merger-for-foley/&text=Holy%20Moly!%20An%20‘Incestuous’%20Law%20Firm%20Merger%20For%20Foley?)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/04/holy-moly-an-incestuous-law-firm-merger-for-foley/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/04/holy-moly-an-incestuous-law-firm-merger-for-foley/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

The Foley Friedman law firm family circle?

Almost two years ago, Foley & Lardner left Eversheds [standing at the altar](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/11/foley-lardner-to-leave-eversheds-standing-at-the-altar/). Since then, the U.K. firm has partnered with Sutherland Asbill & Brennan to become [Eversheds Sutherland](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/whirlwind-romance-leads-to-global-biglaw-merger/), but Foley still finds itself all alone.

Single and ready to mingle once more, it looks like Foley has found the perfect merger match in Friedman Kaplan Seiler & Adelman, a New York litigation boutique with strong ties to Foley. In fact, Friedman Kaplan has so many ties to Foley that the Biglaw firm might as well be marrying its law firm cousin. As we [mentioned](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/04/morning-docket-04-26-17/) earlier today, the whole affair seems to be a bit “incestuous.”

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Don’t believe us? Here’s more information from [Am Law Daily](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202784349808/Foley--Lardner-Explores-Union-With-New-Yorks-Friedman-Kaplan):

Friedman Kaplan, a 46-lawyer boutique that handles mainly litigation, has strong ties to Foley & Lardner. The latter opened in New York back in 2004 after [absorbing New York litigation firm Friedman, Wang & Bleiberg](http://www.bizjournals.com/milwaukee/stories/2004/06/28/daily19.html). Peter Wang, a name partner at that firm, currently serves as managing partner of Foley & Lardner’s New York office. [Wang’s son](http://www.nytimes.com/2004/03/14/style/weddings-celebrations-amy-lief-jeffrey-wang.html), Jeffrey Wang, is a litigator [who made partner](http://www.newyorklawjournal.com/id=1202483796196/NY-Lawyers-Making-Partner) at Friedman Kaplan in 2011. And the family connections don’t stop there.

Jonathan Friedman, [a son](http://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/12/fashion/weddings/12burgess.html) of Friedman Kaplan founding partner Edward Friedman, is currently senior counsel with Foley & Lardner’s litigation and dispute resolution group in New York. (Arthur Friedman, a former Friedman Wang name partner who [died at 79 in 2006](http://www.newyorklawjournal.com/id=900005452041), is unrelated to the other Friedmans.) Foley & Lardner and Friedman Kaplan, which have been adverse on some client matters, are [currently working together representing](http://www.law360.com/florida/articles/913116/timber-co-will-pay-73m-to-end-stock-drop-suit) forestry company Rayonier Inc. in securities litigation in a Florida federal court.

Mum is apparently the word on this potential merger, as no one from either firm was willing to or available to comment. Luckily, you can legally marry your cousin in New York, so Foley should be in the clear for this would-be merger. Best wishes!

[Foley & Lardner Explores Union With New York’s Friedman Kaplan](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202784349808/Foley--Lardner-Explores-Union-With-New-Yorks-Friedman-Kaplan) [Am Law Daily]

# Kirkland & Ellis Places Bonuses In Stockings -- We Need Your Help To Break Open This Black Box
## Bigger than market bonuses at Biglaw mainstay...
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onDecember 20, 2016 at 12:07 PMDecember 21, 2016 at 10:54 AM
0
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/kirkland-ellis-places-bonuses-in-stockings-we-need-your-help-to-break-open-this-black-box/&text=Kirkland%20&%20Ellis%20Places%20Bonuses%20In%20Stockings%20—%20We%20Need%20Your%20Help%20To%20Break%20Open%20This%20Black%20Box)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/kirkland-ellis-places-bonuses-in-stockings-we-need-your-help-to-break-open-this-black-box/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/kirkland-ellis-places-bonuses-in-stockings-we-need-your-help-to-break-open-this-black-box/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
UPDATE (12/21/2016, 10:55 a.m.): Thanks, Kirkland tipsters, for all the [additional data points on K&E bonuses](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/update-bunches-of-kirkland-and-ellis-above-market-bonus-news/).

Kirkland & Ellis has started spreading holiday cheer, making calls and scheduling meetings with associates to inform them of exactly where they sit on K&E’s naughty and nice list. The good news is that associates seem to be getting above-market bonuses. The bad news is that we don’t know if these reports are universal or not.

Because, of course, Kirkland is one of those firms that distributes its bonuses individually, making it harder to report on. But with your help we’ll bust this closed system wide open. If you’re at Kirkland, let us know what you’re getting or what you’re hearing from others. We keep everything anonymous and we’ll obscure identifying details.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
But until we get more intel, here’s what the first tipsters have reported:

Midlevel with above class rating, 2400-2500 hours. Got 1.3x market. Not thrilled. People with a lower rating and sub-2000 hours are still getting above market bonuses, which is great for them, but I feel like a sucker for working harder.

But work is its own reward! This is precisely why I never liked individualized bonuses. With a lockstep system, everyone feels like they’re treated fairly even if the fickle billable gods mean you work 2500 hours one year and merely 2100 the next.

Kirkland associates getting bonus calls and meetings. As always, individualized, but medians are over market. Class of 2011, average hours… just north of $100k.

As a reminder, the Cravath-dictated market scale for 2011 is $80K, so that’s a nice premium.

But give us more tips to work with, Kirkland people! [Email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”) or text us (646-820-8477) with your bonus experience. We’ll keep you anonymous, but everyone benefits the more information we have.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

# New York Biglaw Firms May Be Signaling Trouble Ahead By Not Beating Market Bonuses
## This conservative bonus season may be just the beginning....
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onDecember 19, 2022 at 3:16 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/new-york-biglaw-firms-may-be-signaling-trouble-ahead-by-not-beating-market-bonuses/&text=New%20York%20Biglaw%20Firms%20May%20Be%20Signaling%20Trouble%20Ahead%20By%20Not%20Beating%20Market%20Bonuses)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/new-york-biglaw-firms-may-be-signaling-trouble-ahead-by-not-beating-market-bonuses/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/new-york-biglaw-firms-may-be-signaling-trouble-ahead-by-not-beating-market-bonuses/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
A lot of firms are trying to be more conservative given the question of what 2023 will look like. There is a lot of partner talk about uncertainty and a feeling that a slowdown is coming. Some firms might be trying to flesh out their fiscal year and calm partner nerves.

But I have been surprised that we haven’t seen more New York firms jump into the bonus game. I suspect most of those firms will have strong financial results in terms of revenue per lawyer and profits per partner. Those high-performing, elite firms don’t want to be accused of experiencing significant growth in partner compensation and not passing that down to associates.

— [Kristin Stark](https://fairfaxassociates.com/our-people/kristin-stark/), a legal consultant and principal at Fairfax Associates, in comments given to the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2022/12/16/some-law-firms-offer-superstar-bonuses-as-many-others-tread-carefully-amid-uncertainty/), concerning the fact that the majority of Biglaw firms have [matched](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/biglaw-bonus-tracker-2022/) the [Baker McKenzie base bonus scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/11/biglaw-bonus-season-begins/), rather than exceed it, perhaps due to the threat of a looming recession.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# Elite Biglaw Firm Raises Salaries For All Associates
## Be sure to thank this firm for planting the idea of salary raises in law firm leaders' minds.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 16, 2021 at 4:38 PM
43
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/elite-biglaw-firm-raises-salaries-for-all-associates/&text=Elite%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Raises%20Salaries%20For%20All%20Associates)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/elite-biglaw-firm-raises-salaries-for-all-associates/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/elite-biglaw-firm-raises-salaries-for-all-associates/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Well, well, well. It looks like it’s finally time for DLA to pay the Piper. See what I did there? Two can play at this game, Joe Patrice!

As we just heard from numerous sources, DLA Piper has decided to match the new prevailing market salary scale that was set by Davis Polk just last week.

Here’s what the new salary scale looks like at the firm, in each of its U.S. offices (DLA delineates salaries up to the Class of 2012+; it is only the third firm to do so):

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
- 2020: $205,000
- 2019: $215,000
- 2018: $240,000
- 2017: $275,000
- 2016: $305,000
- 2015: $330,000
- 2014: $350,000
- 2013: $365,000
- 2012+: $375,000
In all seriousness, perhaps associates owe a debt of gratitude to DLA. Back in March, the firm was the [first to increase salaries](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/dla-piper-2021-salary-raise/) outside of major markets, putting all associates on the then-prevailing $190K pay scale. Several firms quickly followed in the firm’s footsteps, righting their payscales. Prior to DLA’s move on salaries, no one else was even thinking of doing such a thing, much less instituting a major raise such as the one offered by Milbank, that was later one-upped by Davis Polk. Thanks to America’s No. 3 firm for planting this idea in the minds of law firm leaders.

Congratulations to everyone working across the country at DLA Piper!

(Flip to the next page to see the full memo from DLA Piper.)

# We Need To Be More Open As A Profession
By [Jill Switzer](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jillswitzer/)  
onDecember 5, 2018 at 12:35 PMDecember 5, 2018 at 12:22 PM
10
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/we-need-to-be-more-open-as-a-profession/&text=We%20Need%20To%20Be%20More%20Open%20As%20A%20Profession)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/we-need-to-be-more-open-as-a-profession/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/we-need-to-be-more-open-as-a-profession/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
“Transparent” is applied in all kinds of settings, being thrown around like a Frisbee (yes, I am dating myself), and as the desired “new normal” in all kinds of settings, including maybe even ours.

So here’s to transparency within our profession. Addiction of whatever kind, depression, stress, all of them have long been kicked under the rug. It’s always been a badge of shame to be transparent and candid about whether you have an issue or a colleague has an issue. It’s always been something not even whispered about, let alone lent itself to any candor. It’s been a code of silence. But now, ever so slowly, I think those issues are starting to be discussed. It’s time to be open and forthright about those issues that affect more than one quarter of our colleagues. That number is probably low because I think stigma attaches to candor.

Brian Cuban, an ATL columnist, has been very upfront with his struggles against addiction and depression. Just type his name in the ATL search box and a bunch of his columns pop up. Last year, he shared the story of Arizona lawyer Chad Anderson who [refused to be anonymous](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/i-am-a-lawyer-in-recovery-and-i-refuse-to-be-anonymous/) about his battle with alcoholism.  

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Our mental health and substance abuse issues can no longer be ignored. If they exist in Biglaw, you can bet they’re in smaller size firms and solos. How many lawyers have prescriptions for anxiety meds, for sleeping aids, for anti-depressants, and [whatever else might be prescribed](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/09/biglaws-big-problem-with-mental-health-and-substance-abuse/)?

This is not a problem that just other people have; this is a problem that we have and the more transparent we are, the better off we will be, in serving our clients, our firms, and I think most importantly (heresy here) ourselves. 

We need more lawyers like Steven Wall, a Biglaw partner, who [talked about his struggle with alcoholism](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/biglaw-managing-partner-opens-up-about-alcoholism/). Wall nails it when he says that law firms of whatever size depends upon their human capital to grow and flourish and that the wellness of lawyers and support staff is critical to success. Firms are not books of business; they are the human capital that generates and services the business.

As a number of ATL columnists, including me, have pointed out, suicides among lawyers are not going down, but up. The stress and anxiety of the need to do everything perfectly, at least in that lawyer’s mind and others, creates a toxic environment for that lawyer. We practice law; we don’t perfect it, and I think that gets lost in the shuffle of billable hours, networking, pro bono and the myriad other tasks we do. And that doesn’t even take into account personal lives (gee, do we have them?), family matters, raising kids, perhaps taking care of elderly parents and/or adult kids, stressors of a different sort but equally valid and present.

###Sponsored

From Pilot and Above The Law  
Lawyers who are no longer practicing law, not retired but doing something else, identify themselves as “recovering lawyers.” Perhaps there’s something to that, and not just in the mental health/substance abuse sense.

So much of our identity is cloaked in our professional image and reputation.  What if we weren’t lawyers anymore? Then what would we be? We would be people, spouses, parents, children, friends, volunteers, whatever other labels we choose. It wouldn’t be just about being lawyers. It would be about being people who happen to make their livings as lawyers. But for so many of us, being a lawyer is what we are all about and there’s no room for anything else, or, in many cases, for anyone else. A pop quiz: how would you describe yourself if not as a lawyer?

One of the best benefits of writing this column is the emails from thoughtful readers who contribute to my thinking, change it, rearrange it. One reader correctly pointed out that it’s not just perfectionism that creates stress and anxiety for lawyers, it’s the ambiguity that by definition is baked into what we do. We don’t know how a judge is going to rule, we don’t know if a judgment will be overturned on appeal, we don’t know how a jury is going to look at the evidence, the witnesses, even the lawyers, we can’t predict what may happen, we don’t know how a client will react. All of these unpredictables create ambiguity, create anxiety, create stress.  

Being a lawyer requires a tolerance for ambiguity, which is something no one talks about while in law school. No one talks about the daily issues of practice. Yes, there are legal clinics in law school, but no one talks about how difficult practice is and how to cope with it. Billing, collecting, networking, doing the work, relationships (or lack thereof) with opposing counsel, managing staff, running the office and so on, a far from exhaustive list.

The reader also noted that while it may be Biglaw mental health/suicides that garner attention, it’s not just Biglaw. Solos kill themselves, ditto lawyers in small and/or medium-sized firms. No size firm has a lock on depression and despair.

If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Another point the reader made: we don’t know the true reasons why lawyers kill themselves, any more than we know why any person commits suicide, but we do know that lawyers kill themselves. We must acknowledge substance abuse and mental health issues and do what we can to help save the lives of our colleagues whose anguish can become too much to bear.  

My generation of lawyers may be dinosaurs, but none of us, at whatever stage we are in our practices, should be ostriches. 

Jill Switzer has been an active member of the State Bar of California for more than 40 years. She remembers practicing law in a kinder, gentler time. She’s had a diverse legal career, including stints as a deputy district attorney, a solo practice, and several senior in-house gigs. She now mediates full-time, which gives her the opportunity to see dinosaurs, millennials, and those in-between interact — it’s not always civil. You can reach her by email at [oldladylawyer@gmail.com](mailto:oldladylawyer@gmail.com?subject=Your%20ATL%20column).

# A Lawyer Goes To CES2024: The Wrap-Up And 10 Takeaways
## Was it worth the trip?
By STEPHEN EMBRY  
onJanuary 17, 2024 at 4:31 PMJanuary 17, 2024 at 2:19 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/a-lawyer-goes-to-ces2024-the-wrap-up-and-10-takeaways/&text=A%20Lawyer%20Goes%20To%20CES2024:%20The%20Wrap-Up%20And%2010%20Takeaways)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/a-lawyer-goes-to-ces2024-the-wrap-up-and-10-takeaways/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/a-lawyer-goes-to-ces2024-the-wrap-up-and-10-takeaways/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Photo by PATRICK T. FALLON/AFP via Getty Images)

Well, it’s a wrap. [CES](https://www.ces.tech/), the massive, annual consumer electronics show, is now history. To say it’s an extravaganza of epic proportions when it comes to trade shows doesn’t do it justice. It completely subsumes Las Vegas for about a week, from the Convention Center on one end of the strip to the Mandalay Bay Resort on the other. And all points in between.

I have been attending for many years mainly to see what’s up in the consumer section that may impact legal, whether it be apps, products, or, frankly, ideas. This year did not disappoint. I’ve been covering the show for Above the Law the past week and have [offered several posts](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/stephen-embry/) on events and products relevant to legal. Now that the show is over and I have returned to reality, here are my top 10 overall impressions — both legal related and in general.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
- Some Statistics
First, some statistics, courtesy of the [Consumer Technology Association](https://www.cta.tech/) (CTA), which owns and holds the show. There were over 4,300 exhibitors displaying their wares in various locations. 1,000 of these exhibitors were startups (CTA calls them the world’s “most promising tech pioneers”) housed in the basement of the Venetian Resort known as Eureka Park. Altogether, there were over 135,000 attendees at the show this year. I don’t know if that’s an attendance record. But it certainly felt like we were long past the pandemic pause. The lines were just as long as ever, and even though Las Vegas is a large city used to large conventions, CES was certainly crowded. Everywhere.

- The Exhibitors
Although the numbers suggest there were lots of startups in Eureka Park, it felt like the exhibit space was dominated more than ever by the big players. Samsung. LGE. Panasonic. The exhibit spaces occupied by these and other giants offered more of a performance than information. Let’s face it: It better be good when you have to stand in line for 30 minutes to get into the exhibit space of an industry behemoth. But while these big players had more space, it seemed like the smaller players that used to occupy the South Hall of the Convention Center were not as prevalent. That’s a shame because these are the people I loved talking to for their ideas and passion.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)

In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
- The Exhibit Spaces
CES is technically a consumer product show, but it’s much broader than that. You see this when you look at the layout of the exhibit halls. Perhaps the largest area of exhibit space, for example, is devoted to automotive products. Not only are electric and self-driving cars on display but also all sorts of component parts are exhibited. It’s been said that CES is the world’s largest automotive show. From the looks of things, it may be. Other large sections of exhibit space are devoted to health, the home, appliances, televisions (of course), and various and sundry other electronic products. While the exhibit spaces are organized by and large by type of product, it’s still hard to see it all. And it takes some searching to see those things that could be relevant to the legal marketplace.

- The Keynotes
The keynote speakers were the usual array of CEOs of industry leaders. These companies include Intel, Siemens, Qualcomm, Walmart, and others. The CEO of Microsoft even made a guest appearance in the Walmart keynote, which I discussed in a [previous post](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/navigating-gen-ai-in-legal-insights-from-ces-and-a-dash-of-tequila-thinking/). However, this year’s keynotes seemed a little longer on sales and shorter on ideas and inspiration. I always enjoy the keynotes to hear the leaders of industry talk about the way they approach leadership, innovation, and challenge. And, frankly, to be inspired. Indeed, there was some of that, as my post indicated. I just wish there had been more.

- Gen AI
###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Ahhh, Gen AI, who could forget it. Preshow, it was predicted that CES2024 would be all about Gen AI and not much else. Indeed, there was a lot of Gen AI hype, but honestly, it was not as much as I expected. The discussions and marketing were more about what the products using Gen AI could do. It was refreshing to see the focus where it belonged.

- The Startups
In this vein, one of the most interesting events I attended was the opportunity for 10 startups to pitch to investors and the media. I wrote a[ post](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/ces-start-ups-shun-gen-ai-hype-for-real-world-solutions/) about that event, which was the kick-off to the show’s media days. As I there mentioned, of the 10 startups who pitched, only one offered a pure Gen AI product. The rest talked about products that they believed would solve practical everyday problems. Sometimes it pays to get back to basics.

- The Gadgets
Every time I return from the show, I see all sorts of articles about the products that were unveiled. I also get asked about all the weird and exotic products that were promoted. ([Wired](https://www.wired.com/) had a [nice article](https://www.wired.com/story/ces-2024-gadgets-you-can-buy-right-now/?bxid=5cc9e25a2ddf9c1a7adf4310&cndid=53488591&esrc=WIRED_CRMSeries&source=Email_0_EDT_WIR_NEWSLETTER_0_DAILY_ZZ&utm_brand=wired&utm_campaign=aud-dev&utm_content=WIR_Daily_011224&utm_mailing=WIR_Daily_011224&utm_medium=email&utm_source=nl&utm_term=P4) on the 25 most interesting products exhibited at the show.) And I wonder: How did I miss all these things? But I learned long ago that you can’t see everything at CES. You have to pick your spots and my spots were things that might impact legal. So I missed all the flying cars (they have been there in one form or another for several years), the automated bidets, the smart dog collars, and the automated cat litter box cleaner, etc. Sorry. If you want to know about gadgets, there is amble press available. For me, the show is not about trendy gadgets but about relevance to my field.

- The Educational Sessions
I didn’t get to attend many of the educational sessions. However, there seemed to be lots of discussions about the ethical use of Gen AI. There were lots of sessions devoted to the potential for government regulations. Both are clearly concerns of the consumer tech industry. I didn’t see as many sessions on things like privacy and cybersecurity, the blockchain, or IoT. I’m sure there were some, but it didn’t seem to be as many as in years past. Getting a handle on the industry’s top concerns is always interesting, and the sessions reflect that.

- The Relevance to Legal
So, what was relevant to legal? The notion that good problem-solving is looking for pain points and then devising solutions that meet those pain points head-on. The idea that decisions on how to use Gen AI should be based on an examination first of what we, as lawyers and legal professionals, are uniquely qualified to do. And then using Gen AI to do everything else. The reality that generational changes, increased connectivity, and expectations stemming from AI, as well as more gamers, will all require lawyers to change how we persuade and the tools we use. The possibility of using the metaverse to meet the challenge of a lack of trial and courtroom experience in younger (and sometimes older lawyers). The need for legal tech vendors to get a handle on what their true customers need before firing off products that don’t accomplish anything except to heighten lawyer skepticism about technology. I come to CES to get these kinds of insights and this year did not disappoint.

- The Bottom Line
Bottom line, what is the show really about? For me, it’s all about the ideas. There are lots of products displayed on the exhibit floor that, for many reasons, will never hit the consumer market. These are the silly gadgets that get attention. But I like the fact that you see people pushing the envelope. It’s inspiring to be around these people. And the show is truly an international one. There are people present from almost every country. You hear countless languages being spoken. You are exposed to multiple cultures. That, too, is inspiring, especially coming from legal tech, where the conversations and product offerings often seem just to repeat themselves. I attend CES for the exposure to the new and different. It’s worth it.

So, there you have it. My wrap up for this year’s CES. Was it worth the trip, the standing in line, walking the endless exhibit floors, and hearing countless sales pitches?

You bet. Always is.

Stephen Embry is a lawyer, speaker, blogger and writer. He publishes [TechLaw Crossroads](https://www.techlawcrossroads.com/), a blog devoted to the examination of the tension between technology, the law, and the practice of law.

### [ Hot Mic Incident Leads Judge To Recusals ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/hot-mic-incident-leads-judge-to-recusals/)
Some things we keep to ourselves until the trial is over.

[Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/biglaw/)
# Biglaw Firms Are Firing With One Hand, Hiring With The Other
## Biglaw giveth, and Biglaw taketh away.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onFebruary 22, 2023 at 5:47 PMFebruary 23, 2023 at 10:21 AM
21
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/biglaw-firms-are-firing-with-one-hand-hiring-with-the-other/&text=Biglaw%20Firms%20Are%20Firing%20With%20One%20Hand,%20Hiring%20With%20The%20Other)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/biglaw-firms-are-firing-with-one-hand-hiring-with-the-other/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/biglaw-firms-are-firing-with-one-hand-hiring-with-the-other/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
They’re doing that with the one hand, while with the other hand more aggressively recruiting in higher performing groups of people.

— [Kent Zimmermann](https://www.consultzg.com/people/kent-zimmermann/), a law firm management consultant with the Zeughauser Group, in comments given to [Bloomberg Law](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/law-firms-mix-hiring-firing-to-protect-profits-amid-uncertainty) on how Biglaw firms are “cleaning up” their workforces by counseling out underperformers, while at the same time bringing on lateral associates, partners, and entire practice groups.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).
