# 'From The Inside Out' With Nancy Saltzman
## Nancy discussed with us the value of law firm experience and what she looks for when working with outside counsel.
By [Above the Law](https://abovethelaw.com/author/above-the-law/)  
onJanuary 8, 2019 at 4:03 PMJanuary 9, 2019 at 12:20 PM
4
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/01/from-the-inside-out-with-nancy-saltzman-of-exl-service/&text=‘From%20The%20Inside%20Out’%20With%20Nancy%20Saltzman)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/01/from-the-inside-out-with-nancy-saltzman-of-exl-service/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/01/from-the-inside-out-with-nancy-saltzman-of-exl-service/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The following is a summary and highlights of Part 3 of our podcast series “From the Inside Out,” bringing non-obvious insights from in-house legal departments to law firms and other lawyers on the outside. “From the Inside Out” is hosted by Ian [Connett](https://www.linkedin.com/in/ian-connett-326a591a/) of [Evolve the Law](https://abovethelaw.com/legal-innovation-center/) and sponsored by [Lake Whillans](http://bit.ly/2RwCSZG), a commercial litigation finance firm with offices in California and New York.

In our third installment, we sat down with [Nancy Saltzman](https://www.linkedin.com/in/nancysaltzman), the former Executive Vice President, Chief Compliance Officer, General Counsel, and Corporate Secretary of [EXL Service](https://www.exlservice.com/), an operations management and analytics company based in New York. Nancy discussed with us the value of law firm experience and what she looks for when working with outside counsel.


Nancy has more than 20 years experience advising large global organizations in complex economic and regulatory environments. She has deep experience in healthcare, insurance, and technology, as well as subject matter expertise in data analytics, robotics process automation, data privacy, and cybersecurity.

Nancy was one of eight members of the executive committee at EXL, which has 27,000 employees globally. The committee’s role is to take stock of where the company is, what its market potential is, where they need to be, and what their investors and the analysts who follow their stock are expecting, and devise a strategy for the company looking at both short- and long-term objectives. EXL handles what they call “business as usual” or “nuts and bolts” legal work in-house, while turning to outside counsel for less-frequent or more high-stakes matters like large litigations, large M&A deals, or legal matters involving employees in states where they have no state law expert.

How did your significant law firm experience prepare you for your career?

Law firm experience is a fantastic training ground — the volume and complexity of transactions and the senior mentorship are second to none. It’s a demanding environment, but you get an enormous amount of education and exposure to the best and brightest minds and the most interesting transaction types in a very short amount of time. It’s a great starting point and there’s no substitute for that kind of training.

Do you look for law firm experience when you’re hiring?

Not all countries have the same path through law school and law firms for training, but in the U.S., we absolutely look for law firm experience and won’t hire anyone with less than three, or ideally five, years of experience. We don’t have the time and energy to train someone from day one on the most basic tenets of legal work.

What’s one thing that law firms just don’t understand about the in-house world?

For the most part, firms don’t understand the incredible demand on budget. It’s more obvious on large transactions, but less so on smaller matters that can meander with no clear end. Law firms tend to be too theoretical and don’t stop to realize that all of that is costing the client time and money. Winning isn’t always the most important thing — often it’s about finding the most cost- and time-effective way to extricate the company from the problem.

Should law departments be viewed as cost centers, and what can firms do to help change that perception?

A legal department should never attempt to be a revenue center, but it serves a purpose where you can create a very good return on investment, where the calculation for the cost of capital, staff, and overhead can not only justify itself but be a value-add. It’s about improving the time to revenue for what you’re producing. Law firms have tools and technologies available to help clients manage, keep up with, and track what’s going on in cases, but they’re not implementing it fast enough.

What do the best law firms do consistently well that keeps them on your roster?

Our go-to firms 1) have come up with a smart staffing approach that’s cost-efficient, 2) have invested the time in knowing our company and learning its culture, and 3) are proactive in how they service our business. It’s great when law firms proactively share specific information that might be of concern to the company and its future.

If you could change one thing about the traditional law firm model, what would it be and why?

There still aren’t enough women and there still isn’t enough diversity across the board. When I put out RFPs, I mandate that the team presented be a diverse team and mandate that the people being identified in the proposal are actually the people who are going to show up and do the work. You have to hold the firms accountable.

Listen to our entire discussion with Nancy Saltzman here to gain more insights from the in-house world.

# Cravath Cracks On Non-Equity Partnerships
## The firm that built the traditional law firm model adds an income partnership tier.
By [Chris Williams](https://abovethelaw.com/author/cwilliams/)  
onNovember 7, 2023 at 2:21 PMNovember 7, 2023 at 3:04 PM
6
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/cravath-cracks-on-non-equity-partnerships/&text=Cravath%20Cracks%20On%20Non-Equity%20Partnerships)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/cravath-cracks-on-non-equity-partnerships/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/cravath-cracks-on-non-equity-partnerships/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Here’s your salary, partner.

For a very long time, being partner at a law firm meant something. Equity partners were all in it together,  sharing the firm’s risks and benefits. Over time the title has diluted — as non-equity “partnerships” became [fancy versions of what used to be Counsel positions](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/08/repeat-after-me-partnership-without-equity-is-not-a-partnership/). Worse, they’re often career dead-ends for women and minorities that the firm [can present as “partners” without actually sharing the wealth](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/yup-nonequity-partnership-is-used-disproportionately-for-minorities/).

After holding out for years, Cravath has decided to join in on the two-tier partner wave.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
From [Bloomberg Law](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/cravath-adds-salaried-partner-tier-in-latest-wall-street-shift?source=breaking-news&item=headline&region=featured-story):

Cravath, Swaine & Moore has quietly created a salaried partner tier, making it the latest in a series of Wall Street law firms to revamp pay schemes in response to new competitive forces.

The firm “recently established the salary partner role,” Faiza Saeed, Cravath’s presiding partner, said Tuesday in an internal memo viewed by Bloomberg Law.

The firm says the move enables them to promote and retain senior talent. Sounds like lawyer speak for Cravath has a lot of attorneys that it doesn’t see as potential equal terms partners. Is this generation really just not up to the standards of yesteryear or are the folks at the top just holding on too tightly these days?

Cravath is unlikely to be the last firm to do this, rumblings have been underway that [Paul Weiss](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/10/25/paul-weiss-could-adopt-nonequity-partner-tier-in-2024/) is also considering the change. At least one thing is for sure — [this bit of trivia](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/theres-only-one-type-of-partner-at-these-biglaw-firms-the-equity-kind/2/) is no longer accurate.

# Unlike Most Biglaw Firms, This Top Contender Has Steadily Increased Associate Hiring
## Lateral associate candidates can find a potential home at this top firm.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onApril 4, 2024 at 4:02 PMApril 4, 2024 at 3:09 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/unlike-most-biglaw-firms-this-top-contender-has-steadily-increased-associate-hiring/&text=Unlike%20Most%20Biglaw%20Firms,%20This%20Top%20Contender%20Has%20Steadily%20Increased%20Associate%20Hiring)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/unlike-most-biglaw-firms-this-top-contender-has-steadily-increased-associate-hiring/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/unlike-most-biglaw-firms-this-top-contender-has-steadily-increased-associate-hiring/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

We want to be thoughtful and disciplined and not over-react to short-term demand cycles.

— [Brad Karp](https://www.paulweiss.com/professionals/partners-and-counsel/brad-s-karp), chair of Paul Weiss, in comments given to Jenna Greene of [Reuters](https://www.reuters.com/legal/litigation/column-amid-lagging-associate-hires-why-these-law-firms-bucked-trend-2024-04-03/), on the firm’s strategic growth over the past three years, during a time when other firms significantly reduced their associate hiring. As noted by Greene, Paul Weiss has added lateral associates at a steady clip, gradually increasing each year: 62 in 2021, 73 in 2022, and 113 in 2023.

# Former Skadden Associate Who Pleaded Guilty In Mueller Probe Begs For No Jail Time
## He's already lost his Biglaw career, isn't that punishment enough?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 30, 2018 at 12:28 PMMarch 31, 2018 at 10:17 AM
40
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/former-skadden-associate-who-pleaded-guilty-in-mueller-probe-begs-for-no-jail-time/&text=Former%20Skadden%20Associate%20Who%20Pleaded%20Guilty%20In%20Mueller%20Probe%20Begs%20For%20No%20Jail%20Time)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/former-skadden-associate-who-pleaded-guilty-in-mueller-probe-begs-for-no-jail-time/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/former-skadden-associate-who-pleaded-guilty-in-mueller-probe-begs-for-no-jail-time/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Alex van der Zwaan (Photo by Win McNamee/Getty Images)

Late last month, Alex van der Zwaan, a former associate at the London office of Skadden Arps, was indicted by special counsel Robert Mueller for lying to investigators in the Russia probe about his communications with former Trump campaign aide Rick Gates, and pleaded guilty shortly thereafter. Earlier this week, he again entered a plea before the court — this time, for leniency in sentencing.

In a sentencing memo submitted to Judge Amy Berman Jackson by his lawyer, Cooley partner William Schwartz, Van der Zwaan, who faces up to six months in prison, says that jail time isn’t necessary in his case, since he’s already “been serving a sentence while stuck in limbo” here in the United States. As noted in the memo, Van der Zwaan “has been alone, separated from his wife; he has lost his job and his career; and he has to live with the knowledge that his suffering and that of his family is due to his own actions.” Isn’t that punishment enough?

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Van der Zwaan claims that he initially lied to investigators to protect his career; after all, he was represented by Skadden lawyers during his first interview with the Office of the Special Counsel, and he assumed that “anything he shared with the OSC would simultaneously be heard by Skadden.” Two weeks later, unaccompanied by Skadden attorneys, Van der Zwaan returned to the U.S. to correct the record, presenting evidence against himself to Mueller’s team.

Though his conduct was “inexcusable,” Van der Zwaan says his cooperation and remorse are “compelling mitigating factors in considering just punishment.” Mueller’s team politely disagrees. The [National Law Journal](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2018/03/28/ex-skadden-associate-charged-in-muellers-russia-probe-seeks-non-jail-sentence/) has the details:

In their own memo, lawyers for Mueller told the judge she should not rule out prison time, due to a “scarcity of mitigating factors, and several aggravating circumstances.” They said van der Zwaan “is a person to whom every advantage in life has been given,” and that the government rightly expected “candor and uprightness” from him.

“While there might eventually be additional professional consequences that befall a foreign lawyer who commits a United States felony, those consequences do not themselves obviate the need for his current sentence to reflect the seriousness of his crime, to promote respect for the law, or to provide adequate specific and general deterrence,” prosecutors wrote.

Best of luck to Alex van der Zwaan — whose career has “turned to dust” — as he attempts to stay out of jail. According to his sentencing memo, “[h]is days are empty and lonely,” and we imagine they’ll only get worse if he actually has to serve time in jail instead of “serving a sentence” in a hotel.

# Arson Trial Ends With Lawyer's Pants On Fire -- Not A Metaphor, His Pants Caught Fire
## The dumbest closing argument ever?
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onMarch 9, 2017 at 10:46 AMMarch 9, 2017 at 5:14 PM
293
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/03/arson-trial-ends-with-lawyers-pants-on-fire-not-a-metaphor-his-pants-caught-fire/&text=Arson%20Trial%20Ends%20With%20Lawyer’s%20Pants%20On%20Fire%20—%20Not%20A%20Metaphor,%20His%20Pants%20Caught%20Fire)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/03/arson-trial-ends-with-lawyers-pants-on-fire-not-a-metaphor-his-pants-caught-fire/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/03/arson-trial-ends-with-lawyers-pants-on-fire-not-a-metaphor-his-pants-caught-fire/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Attorney Stephen Gutierrez faced a trial by fire yesterday afternoon when his pants actually caught flame during his closing arguments. In an arson case.

And they say irony is dead.

Gutierrez, a 28-year-old Miami lawyer, was in the midst of his closing argument — that his client’s car was beset by “spontaneous combustion” — when smoke began to emerge from his pants and he rushed out of the courtroom. Spontaneous combustion? Hey, if it’s good enough for the Ancient Aliens set, it’s good enough for a Florida courtroom.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
But the fact that Gutierrez unexpectedly burst into flames during an impassioned plea to believe in spontaneous combustion has more than a few questioning if this wasn’t a stunt gone wrong. Where there’s smoke, there’s fire, critics say. From the [Miami Herald](http://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/crime/article137317553.html):

Stephen Gutierrez, who was arguing that his client’s car spontaneously combusted and was not intentionally set on fire, had been fiddling in his pocket as he was about to address jurors when smoke began billowing out his right pocket, witnesses told the Miami Herald.

He rushed out of the Miami courtroom, leaving spectators stunned. After jurors were ushered out, Gutierrez returned unharmed, with a singed pocket, and insisted it wasn’t a staged defense demonstration gone wrong, observers said.

First of all, if this were staged, this guy just upped the bar for “zealous representation.” Lighting yourself aflame? Top that with your overnight contempt detainment. Second, what exactly would he have expected a stunt, in an ideal world, to look like? “Ladies and gentlemen of the jury, you may not believe in spontaneous combustion, but behold! Flame on!” Then, after a round of gasps, the case is promptly thrown out and Gutierrez confidently exits the building.

### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
There’s no way anyone storyboards this out that ends well. Wouldn’t you make a trial run at home to see what it looks like? At least to see how badly you’d roast your chestnuts over that open fire. The timing is suspicious, but it’s hard to imagine anyone thinking this would be a good idea.

On the other hand, Gutierrez blames an exploding e-cigarette, which [absolutely happens](https://www.theguardian.com/society/video/2016/nov/04/no-smoke-without-fire-e-cigarette-explodes-in-mans-pocket-video) because vapes are the Galaxy Notes of nicotine delivery methods. I recognize that a lot is being made of Gutierrez fiddling in his pocket before the incident, but he’s a vaper. Have you ever met someone who vapes? Above the Law’s own Elie Mystal vapes and he clutches that thing like it’s the frigging One Ring. Of course, Gutierrez was fiddling with it during his closing.

For the record, the jury found Gutierrez’s client guilty of second-degree arson.

So, who do you believe?

Do you believe this lawyer's pants caught fire accidentally?

- Liar, liar, and his pants are on fire!
- We now live in the darkest of all timelines and literally any coincidence is possible.

# 2022 Was A Good Year For Associate Compensation
## Don't expect a similar increase in 2023.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMarch 1, 2023 at 6:18 PMMarch 2, 2023 at 4:10 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/associate-compensation-rise-biglaw/&text=2022%20Was%20A%20Good%20Year%20For%20Associate%20Compensation)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/associate-compensation-rise-biglaw/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/associate-compensation-rise-biglaw/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

According to Thomson Reuters’ latest State of the Market Report, how much did associate compensation rise in 2022?

Hint: In 2021, associate compensation rose 9.3 percent.

# Which Firms Offer Women The Most Power And Highest Pay? (2016)
## In a profession ruled by men, these Biglaw firms have taken steps to level the playing field for women.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 28, 2016 at 2:01 PM
12
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/which-firms-offer-women-the-most-power-and-highest-pay-2016/&text=Which%20Firms%20Offer%20Women%20The%20Most%20Power%20And%20Highest%20Pay?%20(2016))[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/which-firms-offer-women-the-most-power-and-highest-pay-2016/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/which-firms-offer-women-the-most-power-and-highest-pay-2016/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Each and every year, no matter how much lip service is given to gender equality within the prestigious enclave of Biglaw firms, women continue to be left behind. We’ve [said it once](https://abovethelaw.com/2014/06/which-firms-offer-women-the-most-power-and-highest-pay-2014/), and we’ll say it again: “Biglaw lives to serve men, and in most cases, they are the ones claiming all of the power, the prestige, and most importantly, the money, while women are left in the dust.” At some large law firms, however, it’s a different story. Some firms offer women the chance to rise through the ranks to become major power players and to receive startlingly booming compensation — and rank among the most family-friendly.

Thanks to the [Women in Law Empowerment Forum (WILEF)](http://www.wilef.com/cert2.html), we have a way to find out exactly which firms are on top when it comes to offering women attorneys the chance to perform on par with their male colleagues in terms of prestige and pay.

WILEF offers Biglaw firms with 300 or more lawyers practicing in the United States the chance to become Gold Standard-certified, meaning that they must comply with four of six benchmarks meant to drive women lawyers to succeed in business development and leadership roles. Here are the criteria, which were a bit tougher to achieve this year:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
• Women account for at least 20% of equity partners or alternatively, 33% or more of the attorneys becoming equity partners during the past twelve months. [not a mandatory requirement as previously announced]

• Women represent at least 15% of firm chairs and office managing partners. [Up from 10%]

• Women make up at least 20% of the firm’s primary governance committee.

• Woman represent 20% or more of the firm’s compensation committee.

• Women make up at least 25% of practice group leaders or department heads.

• Women represent at least 15% of the top half of the most highly compensated partners. [Up from 10%]

In addition to the above changes to the second and sixth criteria, the definition of equity partner for purposes of completing the application has changed. The new definition is: “equity partner” is one who receives no more than half of his or her income on a fixed-income basis. Because WILEF had not previously announced this new definition, criteria one will not be a mandatory requirement.

This year, with WILEF’s more stringent requirements, 31 firms made the cut, compared to last year’s showing of 44 firms. Biglaw firms continue to tout their commitment to women’s initiatives, yet once again, not even half of the Am Law 100 appears on this list. For the second year in a row, although WILEF allowed for even bigger law firms to compete for inclusion in its rankings, fewer firms raised the bar for their female attorneys. It’s more than a bit disheartening when you think of it that way.

Here are the [2016 recipients](http://wilef.com/cert2.html) of Gold Standard certification:

Baker, Donelson, Bearman, Caldwell & Berkowitz
Ballard Spahr
Bryan Cave
Cooley
Davis Wright Tremaine
Dentons US
Faegre Baker Daniels
Hogan Lovells
Holland & Hart
Holland & Knight
Jackson Lewis
Jenner & Block
Littler
Manatt, Phelps & Phillips
McCarter & English
Morgan, Lewis & Bockius
Morrison & Foerster
Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe
Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison
Polsinelli
Quarles & Brady
Reed Smith
Shook, Hardy & Bacon
Sidley Austin
Simpson Thacher & Bartlett
Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom
Stoel Rives
Sutherland Asbill & Brennan
Thompson Coburn
Thompson Hine
WilmerHale

From Pilot and Above The Law  
Although WILEF doesn’t tell us how the firms stack up against one another in terms of the criteria needed for certification, we do know that only six firms met all six benchmarks. Those firms are: Davis Wright (recertified for the sixth year in a row); Hogan Lovells (recertified for the fourth year in a row); Holland & Hart (recertified for the fourth year in a row in all six criteria); Quarles & Brady (recertified for the sixth year in a row); Reed Smith (recertified for the sixth year in a row in all six criteria); and Shook, Hardy & Bacon (recertified for the sixth year in a row in all six criteria).

It’s once again worth noting that none of these firms are New York-based, and none of them come close to landing at the top of the firms with the highest profits per partner. Are women only receiving treatment as equals at smaller firms outside big cities?

Under WILEF’s tougher standards, there were some notable dropouts from last year’s certification list. For example, big-name firms like Davis Polk, DLA Piper, K&L Gates, Latham, and Paul Hastings, among many others, have disappeared. We can’t help but to wonder how women are being treated at these firms. If you have any information, please reach out to us [via email](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Women's%20Issues). We keep all of our tipsters anonymous.

Congratulations to all of the firms that met WILEF’s criteria for Gold Standard certification. You have our thanks for rising to the top of the Biglaw pack when it comes to women’s empowerment. We still have a long way to go but these firms are making big strides in the right direction. Thank you for helping women shine in legal practice.

[Under Tougher Standards, 31 Firms Receive WILEF’s Gold Standard Certification](http://wileftribune.com/features/tougher-standards-31-firms-receive-wilefs-gold-standard-certification/) [WILEF Tribune]

# After Over A Year, Allen & Overy and O'Melveny Call Off Merger
## Allen & Overy still wants a major U.S. expansion... but it needs a new partner.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onSeptember 3, 2019 at 11:43 AMSeptember 3, 2019 at 11:39 AM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/09/after-over-a-year-allen-overy-and-omelveny-call-off-merger/&text=After%20Over%20A%20Year,%20Allen%20&%20Overy%20and%20O’Melveny%20Call%20Off%20Merger)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/09/after-over-a-year-allen-overy-and-omelveny-call-off-merger/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/09/after-over-a-year-allen-overy-and-omelveny-call-off-merger/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

A single tear for “Allen O’Melvery”

We’ve branded them a “Will-They-Or-Won’t-They romantic comedy,” but now we know that the answer is definitively “won’t” with [the two firms calling off merger talks](https://www.legalcheek.com/2019/09/allen-overy-and-omelveny-myers-abandon-merger-talks/).

As [recently as July](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/07/morning-docket-07-03-19/), we were hearing that this deal was right around the corner. It made all the sense in the world with Allen & Overy broadcasting a commitment to major expansion in the United States with O’Melveny sitting right there with almost no gap in firm PPP. Why wouldn’t these kids get together and launch [a 3,000-lawyer firm with around $2.8 billion in revenue](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/allen-overy-and-omelveny-are-considering-merger-please-name-it-allen-omelvery/)?

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
But there were problems lingering from the beginning of this saga. Immediately after the story came out, O’Melveny fiercely denied it, declaring, “[We have no plans to merge and never have](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/omelveny-tells-atl-we-have-no-plans-to-merge-and-never-have/).” It was news to Allen & Overy, who didn’t try to lie to the press and [confirmed they were in negotiations with an American firm](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/checking-in-on-allen-omelvery-biglaws-most-hilarious-will-they-or-wont-they-romcom/). To say the firms weren’t on the same page at the time is an understatement — they weren’t on the same document set.

But somehow they got beyond the opening gate stumbles and enjoyed a long courtship complete with reported leadership trips to London and Frankfurt to hash out details. O’Melveny made [concrete changes to its U.K. recruitment efforts](https://www.legalcheek.com/2019/03/email-reveals-decision-on-allen-overy-and-omelveny-myers-mega-merger-due-in-coming-weeks/) in a seeming nod to an impending merger.

Still, rumors swirled that a [small enclave of powerful A&O London partners were opposed to the deal](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/the-allen-omelvery-merger-seems-to-be-gaining-steam/). As the U.K. stares down the barrel of a business cataclysm entirely driven by old Englishmen refusing to embrace economic globalism… this all tracks.

Whether the deal died because of those partners, or the stated reason of troublesome foreign exchange rates, it’s back to the drawing board for Allen & Overy leadership reiterating that expanding in the U.S. “remains the highest priority.”

# Morning Docket: 11.05.18
## * On Friday, Judge Eleanor L. Ross (N.D. Ga.) decided that Georgia's "exact match" voting law was too restrictive, issuing a preliminary injunction against the law just days before the midterm election and ruling that the state must allow those who were flagged by the law -- "individuals who are predominantly minorities" -- to prove their citizenship and identity more easily. Strike one against Republican gubernatorial candidate and Georgia Secretary of State Brian Kemp. [[Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2018/11/03/judge-rules-against-brian-kemp-over-georgia-voting-restrictions-days-before-gubernatorial-election/?utm_term=.b474984d33cf)] * Unwilling to accept his potential fate in the election after having been dealt a blow by Judge Ross, Kemp announced on Saturday that he was investigating the Georgia Democratic Party for allegedly trying to hack the state's voter registration system. Of course, he had little to no evidence to prove these allegations. [[New York Times](https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/04/us/politics/georgia-elections-kemp-voters-hack.html)] * Speaking of the midterm election, you NEED TO VOTE tomorrow. No idea where your polling place is? Not an excuse. Find out right here. Click the link. [[HeadCount](https://www.headcount.org/find-your-polling-place/?polling-location)] * "[O]ut of an abundance of caution due to security concerns," Justice Brett Kavanaugh will skip the walking down the Supreme Court's front steps with the chief justice following his formal investiture ceremony. Every other new justice has done so since 1975 when John Paul Stevens started the tradition. [[Big Law Business](https://biglawbusiness.com/kavanaugh-will-forgo-traditional-walk-down-supreme-court-steps)] * James Polsinelli, name partner and founder of Am Law 100 firm Polsinelli, will be retiring from the firm on January 31, 2019. What will he do after he steps away from Biglaw? "I've got a golf game I’ve neglected for a long time, so I’ll see how much of it I can resurrect," he said. Congratulations on wonderful career! [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/11/02/polsinelli-soon-just-a-brand-name-as-founder-prepares-to-retire/)] * "I get to be a part of history": Denia Perez, a DACA recipient, is the first Dreamer to be admitted to the Connecticut bar. The Quinnipiac Law graduate worked hard to change bar rules so that people like her with U.S. work authorization would be able to practice law in the state. She plans to practice immigration law. [[NECN](https://www.necn.com/news/new-england/Immigrant-Earns-Right-to-Practice-Law-in-Connecticut-499445431.html)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onNovember 5, 2018 at 8:28 AMNovember 4, 2018 at 9:33 PM
1

Strike one against Republican gubernatorial candidate and Georgia Secretary of State Brian Kemp. [[Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2018/11/03/judge-rules-against-brian-kemp-over-georgia-voting-restrictions-days-before-gubernatorial-election/?utm_term=.b474984d33cf)]

* Unwilling to accept his potential fate in the election after having been dealt a blow by Judge Ross, Kemp announced on Saturday that he was investigating the Georgia Democratic Party for allegedly trying to hack the state’s voter registration system. * James Polsinelli, name partner and founder of Am Law 100 firm Polsinelli, will be retiring from the firm on January 31, 2019. What will he do after he steps away from Biglaw? “I’ve got a golf game I’ve neglected for a long time, so I’ll see how much of it I can resurrect,” he said. Congratulations on wonderful career! [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/11/02/polsinelli-soon-just-a-brand-name-as-founder-prepares-to-retire/)]

* “I get to be a part of history”: Denia Perez, a DACA recipient, is the first Dreamer to be admitted to the Connecticut bar. The Quinnipiac Law graduate worked hard to change bar rules so that people like her with U.S. work authorization would be able to practice law in the state. She plans to practice immigration law. [[NECN](https://www.necn.com/news/new-england/Immigrant-Earns-Right-to-Practice-Law-in-Connecticut-499445431.html)]

# New York To $190K -- No, Cravath Didn't Make The First Move
## The next associate salary war is beginning.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/) and [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 4, 2018 at 1:48 PMJune 5, 2018 at 2:18 PM
647
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/new-york-to-190k-no-cravath-didnt-make-the-first-move/&text=New%20York%20To%20$190K%20—%20No,%20Cravath%20Didn’t%20Make%20The%20First%20Move)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/new-york-to-190k-no-cravath-didnt-make-the-first-move/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/new-york-to-190k-no-cravath-didnt-make-the-first-move/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Honestly, we did not expect to see an associate salary bump this year. But OMG, here comes the next wave of Biglaw salary wars.

And this time, Cravath isn’t moving first.

No, that honor belongs to Milbank, which shocked everyone at the firm today with a salary increase to put them over the Biglaw masses. The full memo is on the next page.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
New York to 190K, folks! (UPDATE: For some newer Above the Law readers, “NY to [insert dollar amount here]” is just the way law firm salary increases were described for years… but to clarify, Milbank is raising salaries globally [A second tipster suggests that at least the German offices aren’t matching. We can say London and Singapore are though].)

- Classes 18/17 $190,000 (+10,000)
- Class 2016 $200,000 (+10,000)
- Class 2015 $220,000 (+10,000)
- Class 2014 $250,000 (+15,000)
- Class 2013 $275,000 (+15,000)
- Class 2012 $295,000 (+15,000)
- Class 2011 $315,000 (+15,000)
- Class 2010 $330,000 (+15,000)
Said one Milbank tipster of the news:

“!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!”

Yeah, that sums it up.

We’ve got a few more reactions from Milbank tipsters:

- “Put some respeck on my name”
- “summer of 190”
- “WE ARE THE NEW FUCKIN CRAVATH BITCH”
- “I am as shocked as you are.”
But our favorite so far:

HOLY FUCKING SHIT BALLS OF FIRE HOW WERE WE FIRST

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)

ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
It’s safe to say that associates were surprised.

In fairness, Milbank was an early mover in the last salary war, [matching Cravath within hours](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/ny-to-180k-the-first-major-match/), so they’re not shrinking from a good salary bump. But sticking their neck out first hasn’t been their style lately. Looks like the firm’s decided to take on the mantle of industry trailblazer.

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of this stuff. So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches%20Milbank) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches Milbank”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we’ll also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

(The full email is available on the next page.)

Read more about [why Milbank raised salaries here](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/the-reason-why-milbank-raised-associate-salaries/).

And let us know [what’s going to happen next here](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/who-will-match-the-milbank-raise/).

# Ropes & Gray Elects First Female Chair
## Another woman joins the upper echelon of Biglaw leadership.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onNovember 20, 2017 at 11:45 AM
38
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/ropes-gray-elects-first-female-chair/&text=Ropes%20&%20Gray%20Elects%20First%20Female%20Chair)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/ropes-gray-elects-first-female-chair/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/ropes-gray-elects-first-female-chair/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
While women are [better represented](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/07/the-biglaw-firms-with-the-most-female-equity-partners/) among Biglaw equity partnerships than ever before, those numbers remain woefully low considering we’re sufficiently removed from [the 1950s](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/03/you-wont-believe-this-infuriatingly-sexist-law-firm-memo-from-the-1950s/) to expect more parity. The bulk of a firm’s partnership went to law school after 1980 at this point — it’s become increasingly difficult to blame gender imbalance on the Paper Chase-era.

And the only thing more rare than a female equity partner in Biglaw, is a female equity partner at the highest levels of firm leadership. The exceptions, like [Jami McKeon](https://www.morganlewis.com/bios/jmckeon) of Morgan Lewis, [Faiza Saeed](https://www.cravath.com/fsaeed/) of Cravath, or [Therese Pritchard](https://www.bryancave.com/en/people/therese-d-pritchard.html) of Bryan Cave (who we’re sure is [excited about her job](https://abovethelaw.com/2014/10/biglaw-chairperson-entirely-unexcited-about-new-job/)) are few and far between. We learned just last month that Crowell & Moring [booted its female leader after one term](https://abovethelaw.com/2014/10/biglaw-chairperson-entirely-unexcited-about-new-job/), rendering the landscape just a little more sparse.

Ropes & Gray has added another woman to this elite list, announcing that [Julie Jones](https://www.ropesgray.com/biographies/j/julie-h-jones.aspx) will assume the role of firm chair in 2019, marking the first woman to hold the top post in the firm’s 150-year history. She’ll assume the job from [R. Bradford Malt](https://www.ropesgray.com/biographies/m/r-bradford-malt.aspx?AK=malt). Per [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/sites/americanlawyer/2017/11/20/ropes-grays-next-chair-will-be-a-woman/):

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
The leadership transition coincides with Malt’s reaching the firm’s mandatory retirement age of 65 at the end of 2019. The firm’s policy committee, which acts as its governing board, selected Jones as the firm’s next chair after conducting one-on-one consultations with all of the firm’s partners, according to Malt and Ropes & Gray managing partner David Chapin. Chapin is also due to retire at the end of 2019, and he said a similar process would take place next year to determine his successor as managing partner.

Malt, who has been Ropes & Gray’s chairman since 2004, said in an interview that there was “stunning unanimity” among partners that Jones was the right fit as the firm’s next chair.

The decision to announce the change now affords Ropes & Gray the opportunity to convey a smooth leadership transition, assuring clients and the legal community writ large that Ropes & Gray has a consistent, long-term vision.

On the subject of her election, Jones praised Ropes & Gray for its approach to female lawyers:

“I was always judged on merit. We value intelligence, hard work and commitment—and those things are gender-blind,” she said. “I feel lucky because of the values Ropes & Gray has as a firm, and because we’ve always had strong women leaders and I benefited from that. I feel a sense of duty in that regard. I need to continue to demonstrate our commitment to those core values.”

Normally, words like “merit” and “gender-blind” must be taken with enormous grains of salt. Not because they don’t represent laudable goals, but because they’re usually disingenuous cudgels used to justify discrimination: “we only have 5 percent female partners? I can assure you we judge only on merit… we neutrally tallied up everyone’s hours and hers were just low that year she took maternity leave!” But Ropes & Gray may be the exception that employs those words honestly. Jones will step in as chair, and another partner, [Jane Rogers](https://www.ropesgray.com/janerogers), will join the firm’s policy committee.

Congratulations to Jones and Rogers on their new roles.

[Ropes & Gray’s Next Chair Will Be a Woman](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/sites/americanlawyer/2017/11/20/ropes-grays-next-chair-will-be-a-woman/) [American Lawyer]

# Morning Docket: 08.25.16
## * Demand for legal services may be down, but to keep up appearances, law firms are raising their rates. Despite those rate increases -- which are driving revenue across most firms -- Wells Fargo Private Bank's Legal Specialty Group says, "We do not expect the results to match the record peak performance experienced in 2014.” At least you tried? [[WSJ Law Blog](http://blogs.wsj.com/law/2016/08/24/law-firms-keep-battling-weak-demand-by-charging-more/?ref=/blogs/law)] * In-house attorneys make a lot of money, but that won't stop them from being envious of their Biglaw colleagues. Per a new survey, 44 percent of in-house counsel say their compensation is “below or significantly below that of their peers," and 40 percent said they were likely to search for a new job because of comp issues. [[Big Law Business](https://bol.bna.com/in-house-lawyers-make-more-but-not-like-associates/)] * If you missed it this weekend, Joan Biskupic had an excellent profile of Justice Sandra Day O'Connor. Though she once lamented that her decisions were "being dismantled," she's modest about how influential she was on the Supreme Court: "We [tried] to persuade by the strength of the argument. Everyone [had] a very key vote." [[CNN](http://www.cnn.com/2016/08/20/politics/sandra-day-o-connor-legacy/)] * "The current condition of the [Cincinnati College of Law may] not [be] good enough for [its] wonderful students,” but that doesn't mean it's getting a new building any time soon. The school's trustees just scrapped a plan to build a new law school at the downtown riverfront, opting to keep it on UC's main campus. [[Cincinnati Enquirer](http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/2016/08/24/uc-pull-plug-law-school-banks/89270244/)] * "[B]ehind its façade of attainable elegance, Zara is engaged in a widespread practice of deceiving American consumers through a classic bait and switch." Clothing store Zara has been slapped with a $5 million federal suit for allegedly engaging in deceptive pricing tactics. The store typically only lists prices in euros in its U.S. stores. [[Us Weekly](http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-style/news/zara-slapped-with-massive-lawsuit-for-alleged-price-spiking-w435871)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)

# Salary Match, But Bonuses Delayed... Mwahaha, Now You Can NEVER Leave
## When firms delay the summer bonus until the end of the year, you get what they're doing, right?
By [Elie Mystal](https://abovethelaw.com/author/elie-mystal/)  
onJune 28, 2018 at 5:38 PM
4
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/salary-match-but-bonuses-delayed-mwahaha-now-you-can-never-leave/&text=Salary%20Match,%20But%20Bonuses%20Delayed…%20Mwahaha,%20Now%20You%20Can%20NEVER%20Leave)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/salary-match-but-bonuses-delayed-mwahaha-now-you-can-never-leave/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/salary-match-but-bonuses-delayed-mwahaha-now-you-can-never-leave/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


Jenner & Block is on the Cravath salary corner. They’re out with a match of the salary scale.

Jenner & Block is one of the elite firms in Chicago, but they’re probably best known for their top-notch D.C. appellate practice.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
The firm is matching salaries, but not the summer bonuses started off by Simpson Thacher. Instead, the firm said that they will consider that other firms have given out summer bonuses when it comes time to make end of the year payments.

[As Kathryn Rubino has mentioned](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/biglaw-firm-raises-salaries-but-stiffs-associates-on-summer-bonuses-promises-to-make-it-up-at-the-end-of-the-year/), delaying the midyear bonuses — sorry, delaying the possibility of midyear bonuses — until the end of the year has the effect of tying associates to the firm for the rest of the year, and realistically on into the next. Sure, comparatively few people leave their firms during the summer and fall, and the end of year bonuses is always there as an incentive to stay through another year.

But some associates do and now, if they do, they’re looking at missing out on an even bigger bonus, one that many of their colleagues have already earned.

At the very least, the time value of money here benefits the partners.

It’s just another link of the golden handcuffs: Go up a class year and get a big raise at the start of the year, work for a few months, start thinking of leaving, start thinking about how much more money is waiting for you in December, hang on, go up a class year, rinse, repeat. It’s not bad or nefarious. It’s just the cycle of Biglaw.

# Biglaw Partner Benchslapped: 'If You Can't Focus... Sit Down, And I Will Ask The Questions'
## You know things aren't going well when the judge offers to do the job for you.
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onJune 1, 2016 at 1:59 PMJune 2, 2016 at 12:29 PM
4
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/biglaw-partner-benchslapped-if-you-cant-focus-sit-down-and-i-will-ask-the-questions/&text=Biglaw%20Partner%20Benchslapped:%20‘If%20You%20Can’t%20Focus…%20Sit%20Down,%20And%20I%20Will%20Ask%20The%20Questions’)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/biglaw-partner-benchslapped-if-you-cant-focus-sit-down-and-i-will-ask-the-questions/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/biglaw-partner-benchslapped-if-you-cant-focus-sit-down-and-i-will-ask-the-questions/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
[](http://diversity.chambersandpartners.com/women-in-litigation-thurs-march-12-new-york/)
Justice Saliann Scarpulla (via Chambers Diversity)

As John H. Wigmore famously [stated](http://wwwcrossx.blogspot.com/2012/01/cross-examination-and-truth.html), “Cross-examination is the greatest legal engine ever invented for the discovery of truth.” But what happens when that engine… blows up in your face?

Just last week, litigation columnist John Balestriere discussed the importance of [not giving up in cross-examination](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/05/never-give-up-on-cross-examination/). But what do you do when the judge presiding over your case thinks you’ve gone too far?

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
This actually happened to a Quinn Emanuel partner in a recent proceeding, as reported by [Law360](https://www.law360.com/legalethics/articles/801794/judge-offers-to-do-quinn-emanuel-atty-s-job-in-cozen-row):

A New York judge reprimanded a Quinn Emanuel Urquhart & Sullivan LLP attorney for his circuitous questions at a hearing on Tuesday over whether Cozen O’Connor used confidential documents in Fair Isaac Corp.’s $45 million contract suit against a former eBay unit, offering to take over questioning herself.

New York Supreme Court Justice Saliann Scarpulla repeatedly scolded Quinn Emanuel’s [David Grable](http://www.quinnemanuel.com/attorneys/grable-david-m) for delving into what she called “irrelevant” details while he questioned Cozen lawyers and contractors about confidential eBay Enterprise Inc. documents that accidentally fell into the firm’s hands. The judge told Grable to stick to the main issue and threatened to take over questioning if he didn’t.

“This is really the last time I am going to tell you… If you can’t focus that way, sit down and I will ask the questions,” Judge Scarpulla said.

And that wasn’t the only expression of exasperation from Her Honor:

Over the course of the proceeding, Judge Scarpulla grew increasingly impatient and began to interject questions herself.

“I’m getting very frustrated with the amount of irrelevant questions. Either you pick this up or we’re done,” she told Grable.

Ouch. Justice Scarpulla, a Brooklyn Law grad, just showed the L.A.-based Grable how they roll in Kings County.

Whenever we hear of a lawyer getting benchslapped, we instinctively side with the judge. But just because you wear a black robe doesn’t mean you’re always right. If you surf over to [Robing Room](http://www.therobingroom.com/newyork/Judge.aspx?id=1108), you’ll see mixed reviews of Justice Scarpulla. Some praise her as “a rising star” with “a wonderful temperament,” but others claim she’s “very rude and caustic” and “yells for no reason.”

The lawyers from Quinn Emanuel and Cozen O’Connor both declined to comment to Law360 yesterday.

# What Risks Keep You Up At Night?
## Tell us about your worst fears in this anonymous survey and get a chance at a $250 gift card. 
By [Above the Law](https://abovethelaw.com/author/above-the-law/)  
onJanuary 20, 2022 at 11:37 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/what-risks-keep-you-up-at-night/&text=What%20Risks%20Keep%20You%20Up%20At%20Night?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/what-risks-keep-you-up-at-night/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/what-risks-keep-you-up-at-night/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Malpractice lawsuits. Judicial sanctions. Negligent accounting. Social engineering. 

The onslaught of critical business risks can make the legal industry seem like a minefield at times. That’s why we’re asking our readers: What risks keep you up at night? 

Please help us benchmark the industry — and win a chance at a $250 gift card — by taking this (always) brief and anonymous survey.

# Using Reply-All To Show Your Biglaw Firm You're A Jerk
## What a douche.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMay 29, 2018 at 2:46 PMMay 30, 2018 at 2:08 AM
200
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/read-the-nasty-mass-email-sent-at-a-biglaw-firm-over-a-departing-associate/&text=Using%20Reply-All%20To%20Show%20Your%20Biglaw%20Firm%20You’re%20A%20Jerk)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/read-the-nasty-mass-email-sent-at-a-biglaw-firm-over-a-departing-associate/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/read-the-nasty-mass-email-sent-at-a-biglaw-firm-over-a-departing-associate/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Check out the update to the story at the end of the article.

Lateral moves are a regular part of Biglaw life. Perhaps not surprisingly, the firm you selected before you’d even started 2L year is unlikely to be the job you one day retire from. So lots of lawyers move jobs — that’s just something the partnership and management of a firm must accept. And, as with anything built into the culture of a firm, there are certain traditions built around the process — the notice period, handing off cases, the goodbye drinks, and of course, the farewell email.

Now, some associates take the departure memo as [an opportunity to burn all the bridges or show some personality at long last](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/departure-memos/). That isn’t what is happening here. No, just a simple lateral move from Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati to Cooley. And the associate in question sent a perfectly appropriate email to the offices and practice group she’s worked with.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  


Everything almost seems too normal to comment on. That is, until WSGR’s chief financial officer, Jonathan Fayman, decided to insert himself into the conversation. Fayman joined the firm last year, and [according to his WSGR bio](https://www.wsgr.com/WSGR/DBIndex.aspx?SectionName=attorneys/BIOS/15739.htm), does not seem to have any other Biglaw experience.

Mr. Fayman, let me introduce you to Above the Law.

See, when you do dumb things, like send a mean-spirited mass email ripping an associate for having the common courtesy to send a goodbye email to colleagues, we’re going to have something to say. Our network of tipsters is large and we’ve gotten many tips complaining about the email you sent in response to this farewell email, calling it “horrific,” “awful,” and “rude.” One source went so far as to say:

###Sponsored
[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
If he doesn’t get fired for this kind of a behavior, I am leaving.

It seems Fayman fancies himself the email police, and sent an absolutely douche-tastic reply-all response to the farewell email because he doesn’t like emails that don’t directly relate to his position. Rather than deal with the mass emails that are an inevitable part of life in a large organization like an adult, he responds in the nastiest possible way that you absolutely have to read to believe:



What a dick.

Seriously, he only joined the firm in 2017. Did it even occur to him that the accepted standard of behavior is a little different than whatever asset management hell he came from? Also complaining about too many mass emails by sending a mass email is a classic dumbass move that is almost guaranteed to generate even more mass emails in response.

From Pilot and Above The Law  
Fayman must’ve KNOWN that email was a jerk move filled with biting commentary, so what the hell possessed him to hit send… oh wait…



Never fear — Katharine (Katie) Martin, chair of WSGR’s board of directors and an actual attorney at the firm familiar with the traditions of the firm and basic human dignity, shut down Fayman’s nonsense in the most pitch-perfect and delightfully passive aggressive way possible (even though tipsters report the response took 30 minutes while associates were “freaking out about how awful it was”):


I only wish I could have read the backchannel email you know she sent him.

UPDATE 5/29/18 3:21 p.m.: Since we published the story we’ve received additional information. On Friday evening managing partner Douglas Clark also responded with his own mass email letting the firm know — in no uncertain terms — rude emails like the one Fayman sent will not be tolerated by WSGR:

# Lateral Link Partner And Law Firm Survey: The Results Are In
## Congratulations to these leaders in their fields!
By [Lateral Link](https://abovethelaw.com/author/lateral-link/)  
onAugust 5, 2016 at 6:36 PMAugust 5, 2016 at 7:19 PM
6
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/lateral-link-partner-and-law-firm-survey-the-results-are-in/&text=Lateral%20Link%20Partner%20And%20Law%20Firm%20Survey:%20The%20Results%20Are%20In)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/lateral-link-partner-and-law-firm-survey-the-results-are-in/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/lateral-link-partner-and-law-firm-survey-the-results-are-in/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: This is the latest installment in a series of posts from [Lateral Link’s](http://laterallink.com/) team of expert contributors.

We [asked](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/07/half-yearly-survey-bet-the-company/). You voted. The results are in. Unlike lists that are determined by think tanks, editors, and independent researchers, this is who YOU think deserves top billing. Read on for the results!

Who is the top litigator?

[Dan Webb](http://www.winston.com/en/who-we-are/attorneys/webb-dan-k.html), Partner, Winston & Strawn LLP

Co-Chairman of Winston & Strawn, Dan Webb is considered one of the nation’s leading trial attorneys with a long list of wins under his belt. Some of his corporate clients have included American Airlines, Deloitte & Touche, General Electric, and Research In Motion.

How about IP litigator?

[Morgan Chu](http://www.irell.com/professionals-22.html), Partner, Irell & Manella LLP

Perhaps best known for winning the largest damage award ever affirmed on appeal by California courts, Morgan Chu has helped his clients recover more than $5 billion over the course of his career. Chambers has previously described Mr. Chu as “beyond doubt the most gifted trial lawyer in the USA,” who “delivers staggering results for clients.”

Who is the leading M&A partner?

Tie

[Jeffrey Rosen](http://www.debevoise.com/jeffreyrosen), Partner, Debevoise & Plimpton LLP

[Michael Woronoff](http://www.proskauer.com/professionals/michael-woronoff/), Partner, Proskauer Rose LLP

Based in New York, Jeffrey Rosen has previously been recognized in Band 1 for corporate M&A by Chambers Global (2016), having successfully represented Verizon Wireless in its acquisition of Alltel Corporation, and General Electric and NBC for its acquisition of Vivendi Universal Entertainment.

Head of the Los Angeles office and West Coast corporate and securities practice, Michael Woronoff has handled IPOs and other public equity offerings by Alexandria Real Estate Equities, Ares Capital Corporation, Ares Management L.P., General Nutrition Centers, Hamburger Hamlet, Maidenform Brands, Occidental Petroleum, Rentech, RockShox, SEMCO Energy, Smart & Final Stores, Inc. and West Coast Video.

How about real estate finance partner?

[Jesse Sharf](http://www.gibsondunn.com/lawyers/jsharf), Partner, Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher LLP

Consistently recognized as one of the leading real estate finance lawyers, Jesse Sharf is Co-Chair of Gibson Dunn’s Real Estate Department and a member of the firm’s Executive Committee. Mr. Sharf is located in the Century City office, where he has represented a myriad of investors, lenders, and developers over the course of his thirty-year career.

Who is the top capital markets partner?

Tie

[Richard D. Truesdell, Jr.](https://www.davispolk.com/professionals/richard-truesdell/), Partner, Davis Polk & Wardwell LLP

[John-Paul Motley](https://www.omm.com/professionals/john-paul-motley/), Partner, O’Melveny & Myers LLP

Richard Truesdell is Co-Head of Davis Polk’s Capital Markets Group, where he represents clients in both U.S. and international capital markets transactions. His client list includes major investment banks such as Credit Suisse, Goldman Sachs, and J.P. Morgan.

Based out of Los Angeles, J.P. Motley’s client list includes American Honda Finance Corporation, Liberman Broadcasting, Inc., Semtech Corporation, and Toyota Motor Credit Corp., among others. Consistently recognized as a leading lawyer in the space, Mr. Motley serves as Managing Partner of the L.A. office and is on the firm’s Policy Committee and Capital Markets Practice.

How about bankruptcy/insolvency partner?

Tie

[Marcia Goldstein](http://www.weil.com/people/marcia-goldstein), Partner, Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP

[Bruce Bennett](http://www.jonesday.com/bbennett/), Partner, Jones Day

Recognized by The National Law Journal as one of its “100 Most Influential Lawyers in America,” Marcia Goldstein has represented a wide range of clients in all areas of domestic and international debt restructuring and crisis management. Ms. Goldstein is a member of the National Bankruptcy Conference, the American College of Bankruptcy, and the International Insolvency Institute.

Bruce Bennett is located in Los Angeles, where he is a Partner and Global Head of Jones Day’s Business Restructuring & Reorganization Practice. Representing a wide range of clients, including the City of Detroit in its historic chapter 9 debt adjustment case, he is a member of the American College of Bankruptcy and Financial Lawyers Conference.

We hope you will join us this Thursday, August 11th, at 1:30 p.m. ET for a live webinar discussing the recent Cravath-led pay increase and its impact on law firm, corporate, and recruitment practices. Additionally, the panelists will explore the future financial implications of these raises and what they mean for the legal industry. Moderated by Above the Law’s Founder and Managing Editor, David Lat, the panel will feature [John C. Hueston](https://www.hueston.com/attorneys/hueston), Partner at Hueston Hennigan LLP, [Arash Mostafavipour](https://www.linkedin.com/in/arashlaw), General Counsel of Xome, and [Michael Allen](http://laterallink.com/about/team/189), Founder and Principal of Lateral Link.

Earlier: [Lateral Link Half-Yearly Survey: Bet The Company](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/07/half-yearly-survey-bet-the-company/)

[Lateral Link](http://laterallink.com/) is one of the top-rated international legal recruiting firms. With over 14 offices world-wide, Lateral Link specializes in placing attorneys at the most prestigious law firms and companies in the world. Managed by former practicing attorneys from top law schools, Lateral Link has a tradition of hiring lawyers to execute the lateral leaps of practicing attorneys. Click [::here::](http://laterallink.com/about/testimonials) to find out more about us.

# Will Associates At Other Biglaw Firms Unionize?
## It's highly doubtful.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onAugust 7, 2023 at 3:47 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/will-associates-at-other-biglaw-firms-unionize/&text=Will%20Associates%20At%20Other%20Biglaw%20Firms%20Unionize?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/will-associates-at-other-biglaw-firms-unionize/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/will-associates-at-other-biglaw-firms-unionize/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

There basically aren’t limits on what an associate can be asked to do, as long as it’s legal. It seems like a situation ripe for unionizing, but I don’t see it happening.

— [Kate Reder Sheikh](https://www.mlaglobal.com/en/people/kate-reder-sheikh), a legal recruiter in the associate practice group at Major, Lindsey & Africa, in comments given to [Bloomberg Law](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/unionizing-big-law-associates-is-tough-sell-in-competitive-world) on the likelihood that Biglaw associates will decide to unionize. Last month, associates at Outten & Golden [formed a union](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/associates-at-this-law-firm-just-unionized-will-associates-at-other-firms-follow-along/) and the firm formally recognized it.

# Top 20 Biglaw Firm Mandates Vaccination For Employees To Return To Office
## Take a shot to go back to your desk.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJuly 28, 2021 at 4:48 PMJuly 28, 2021 at 2:49 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/paul-weiss-vaccine/&text=Top%2020%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Mandates%20Vaccination%20For%20Employees%20To%20Return%20To%20Office)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/paul-weiss-vaccine/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/paul-weiss-vaccine/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
[V]irtually the entire Paul, Weiss community would strongly prefer working alongside colleagues who are vaccinated.

[To] promote the safest possible working environment, [we] will be requiring everyone who enters our offices to be fully vaccinated.

— An excerpt from a memo sent by Brad Karp, managing partner at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, concerning the firm’s [new vaccination mandate for all employees](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2021/07/27/delta-variant-vaccines-become-central-talking-points-in-law-firm-office-return-plans/). Attorneys and staff are expected to return to the office on September 13, and the firm will lift its in-office mask requirement at that time, as all personnel will be vaccinated.

# Leading West Coast Litigators Announce Bigger, Better Associate Paychecks
## Exciting news!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 18, 2021 at 12:29 PMJune 21, 2021 at 10:57 AM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/gibson-dunn-raise-2021/&text=Leading%20West%20Coast%20Litigators%20Announce%20Bigger,%20Better%20Associate%20Paychecks)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/gibson-dunn-raise-2021/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/gibson-dunn-raise-2021/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The West Coast is the best coast… when it comes to bunches of Biglaw firms piling on to match the new salary scale, all at more or less the same exact time.

Yesterday afternoon, Gibson Dunn — a firm that placed 12th in the most recent Am Law ranking, with $2,160,542,000 gross revenue in 2020 — unleashed the good news for associates, who seemed quite pleased with their new salaries.

Here’s what the new salary scale looks like at the firm:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
- 2021: $202,500
- 2020: $205,000
- 2019: $215,000
- 2018: $240,000
- 2017: $275,000
- 2016: $305,000
- 2015: $330,000
- 2014: $350,000
- 2013: $365,000
New wages at the firm will be effective as of July 1, and summer associates will share in the largesse as well. Congratulations!

(Flip to the next page to see the full memo from Gibson Dunn.)

We depend on your tips to stay on top of this stuff. So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

# This Biglaw Merger Shows How It's Done
## One year in, this Biglaw merger has been incredibly successful.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMarch 7, 2023 at 6:48 PMMarch 8, 2023 at 9:12 AM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/this-biglaw-merger-shows-how-its-done/&text=This%20Biglaw%20Merger%20Shows%20How%20It’s%20Done)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/this-biglaw-merger-shows-how-its-done/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/this-biglaw-merger-shows-how-its-done/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


Ed. Note: Welcome to our daily feature [Trivia Question of the Day!](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/trivia-question-of-the-day/)

The merger of which two Biglaw firms, completed March 1, 2022, reportedly tripled the volume of work firm leaders predicted would come from the merger?

Hint: Firm leaders also confirmed revenue growth at the combined firm outstripped the growth the firms would have reported separately.

See the answer on the next page.

# Are You A Woman Fed Up With Biglaw? You Aren't Alone
## Plus the 3 biggest frustrations for breadwinner woman lawyers.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onAugust 12, 2019 at 4:42 PMAugust 12, 2019 at 2:07 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/08/are-you-a-woman-fed-up-with-biglaw-you-arent-alone/&text=Are%20You%20A%20Woman%20Fed%20Up%20With%20Biglaw?%20You%20Aren’t%20Alone)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/08/are-you-a-woman-fed-up-with-biglaw-you-arent-alone/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/08/are-you-a-woman-fed-up-with-biglaw-you-arent-alone/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
In the latest episode of The Jabot podcast, I talk with Jen Dawson, co-author of [What Do Breadwinner Women Lawyers (BWLs) Want?](https://www.hemingtonwm.com/breadwinner-women-lawyers/) and Managing Director of [Hemington WealthManagement](https://www.hemingtonwm.com/lawyers/). Jen and I discuss the biggest frustrations that women in the legal profession have, tips to improve your financial health, and why women lawyers are so unhappy.

The Jabot podcast is an offshoot of the Above the Law brand focused on the challenges women, people of color, LGBTQIA, and other diverse populations face in the legal industry. Our name comes from none other than the Notorious Ruth Bader Ginsburg and the jabot (decorative collar) she wears when delivering dissents from the bench. It’s a reminder that even when we aren’t winning, we’re still a powerful force to be reckoned with.

Happy listening!

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, and host of [The Jabot podcast.](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA) AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](https://twitter.com/Kathryn1)).

###Sponsored
