# The Future Ready Lawyer Survey 2022: Addressing The Growing Pressure On Law Firms
## There are multiple factors identified as drivers of change within law firms, and there is now rough consensus that technology is one of those factors for firms.
By [Ken Crutchfield](https://abovethelaw.com/author/kcrutchfield/)  
onDecember 6, 2022 at 3:03 PMDecember 6, 2022 at 2:16 PM
40
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/the-future-ready-lawyer-survey-2022-addressing-the-growing-pressure-on-law-firms/&text=The%20Future%20Ready%20Lawyer%20Survey%202022:%20Addressing%20The%20Growing%20Pressure%20On%20Law%20Firms)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/the-future-ready-lawyer-survey-2022-addressing-the-growing-pressure-on-law-firms/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/the-future-ready-lawyer-survey-2022-addressing-the-growing-pressure-on-law-firms/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
This is the second in a series of articles covering the Wolters Kluwer [Future Ready Lawyer Survey 2022](https://images.go.wolterskluwer.com/Web/WoltersKluwer/%7Bf38293b3-9969-4fd4-8fc6-daea89537ff1%7D_LR_white_paper_2022_09-01_FINAL_single.pdf), a global survey that examines the factors that are affecting the future of the legal profession, and how well law firms and law departments are prepared to address them.

[Last month](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/the-future-ready-lawyer-survey-2022-the-impacts-of-volatility-on-the-practice-of-law/), I covered several key findings, including the volatility, uncertainty, complexity, and ambiguity (VUCA) that has become part of the new normal for legal professionals and is the backdrop to the significant pressure that is driving change in the profession. Law departments are feeling the pressure and, as a result, are putting extra pressure on their law firms (recall that 32% of lawyers in-house indicated they are very likely to switch firms in the upcoming year).

There are multiple factors identified as drivers of change within law firms, and there is now rough consensus that technology is one of those factors for firms. This includes law firm leadership who, though prior surveys pointed to them as roadblocks to innovation, are no longer seen as such.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
A few weeks ago, I had the distinct honor of facilitating a great panel at the [ARK KM Legal 2022 Conference](https://www.kmlegalconference.com/) based upon the Future Ready Lawyer Survey 2022. During the session we had the opportunity to elaborate on the challenges that firms face and address some potential solutions. In this article, I’ll dive deeper into some of those observations on how law firms can work to address forces of change within the industry, technology gaps they need to overcome, and practices to prepare for the future.

Managing Change Versus Deploying Technology

With a rough consensus on the need for technology, and as law firm leadership begins to support technology projects, why aren’t we seeing better results? A likely reason is that technology in and of itself does not solve any problem; technology has to be part of a larger initiative to address the people and the processes involved to work toward a solution. Focusing on managing change before, during, and after new technology is deployed is critical to success. Soliciting leadership to support change in addition to technology can be a great next step in the maturity of law firms as they embrace technology initiatives. Doing so can help with technology adoption and positive outcomes for firms.

Technology Adoption

From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Successful adoption of technology is a good metric for the success of projects. One way to encourage technology adoption is to publish usage statistics — who is using it, what are users doing, who has yet to log in, etc. Transparency in usage to leadership can also help drive adoption. One great point that [Leanna Simon](https://www.honigman.com/professionals-leanna-r-simon), director of research and knowledge management at[ Honigman](https://www.honigman.com/) made during our ARK panel was that firms do not have a way of crediting time spent on figuring out new technology, so they should look at creating a billable hour for innovation because of the time required.

The Age-Old Question Of The Billable Hour

One perpetual challenge that law firms face is the dependence on billing by the hour. On the surface, technology productivity can reduce billable hours and hence reduce revenues — which doesn’t sound like a great argument to make the case for tech adoption.

But focusing on lost billable hours misses the competitive benchmark. Let’s consider the current landscape: more work is going in-house to law departments, there is increasing competition from Alternative Legal Service Providers (ALSPs), and competing law firms that deploy technology to be more efficient are going to set the standard for the number of hours it takes to complete a matter. [Dave Majors,](https://www.linkedin.com/in/dave-majors-a554351/) director, knowledge management strategy and operations at [Sidley Austin](https://www.sidley.com/en/us/), had a great observation on this during our panel discussion when he pointed out the difference between billable hours and realization (hours actually paid for by the client). “A great way to advance technology solutions is to focus on increasing the realization of work and eliminating time that can’t be billed,” he said.

Killer Apps

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
When it comes to prioritizing new projects, one area to consider is the “Killer App.” A killer app allows you to do something that isn’t currently possible.  Years ago, discovery required sorting through bank boxes; but once e-discovery came along, it changed that workflow entirely. [Andrew Brinkman](https://www.linkedin.com/in/andrew-brinkman-a0691a12/), global director of knowledge management at [Fried Frank](https://www.friedfrank.com/), said, “Look for problems where there is a ‘force multiplier.’ In other words, apply technology to empower attorneys to do something that they never could do before.” If you can solve these problems, change and adoption solve themselves.

But how do you find the problem that can be solved with a killer app? [Scott Kaiser](https://www.paulhastings.com/professionals/scottkaiser), practice innovation and knowledge attorney at [Paul Hastings](https://www.paulhastings.com/), said, “It’s about relationships and understanding the attorneys you support.  Start with talking with attorneys regularly, doing analysis and collecting facts.” By doing this, you’ll understand the problems and how to get buy-in for projects, including the proverbial killer app.

The pressures on law firms to perform is greater than ever given the volatility and uncertainty in the world today. As the regulatory and compliance landscape continues to become more complex and saturated with information, clients need guidance from their law firms more than ever before. Law firms can be more innovative and apply technology to be more client-responsive. In turn, they will be able to focus, remain competitive, and thrive in the years to come.

Next month, I’ll examine how law departments can address change and prepare themselves for the future.

Ken Crutchfield is Vice President and General Manager of Legal Markets at Wolters Kluwer Legal & Regulatory U.S., a leading provider of information, business intelligence, regulatory and legal workflow solutions. Ken has more than three decades of experience as a leader in information and software solutions across industries. He can be reached at [ken.crutchfield@wolterskluwer.com](mailto:ken.crutchfield@wolterskluwer.com).

# Biglaw Attorney Learns Hard Lesson About When *Not* To Recruit New Lawyers
## The judge was tough but fair about this 'inappropriate' behavior.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJuly 13, 2023 at 12:47 PMJuly 13, 2023 at 11:59 AM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/biglaw-attorney-learns-hard-lesson-about-when-not-to-recruit-new-lawyers/&text=Biglaw%20Attorney%20Learns%20Hard%20Lesson%20About%20When%20*Not*%20To%20Recruit%20New%20Lawyers)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/biglaw-attorney-learns-hard-lesson-about-when-not-to-recruit-new-lawyers/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/biglaw-attorney-learns-hard-lesson-about-when-not-to-recruit-new-lawyers/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Maybe Perkins Coie attorneys think they *always* need to be recruiting potential lateral lawyer talent, but they’re learning there is a time and a place for everything. An unnamed Perkins Coie attorney was benchslapped by Northern District of California Judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers for trying to recruit one of her clerks mid-trial. Yeah, even if you’re uniquely impressed by the legal acumen of a law clerk, it seems like discretion would warrant at least waiting until the end of trial to try to recruit them to your firm.

But, as[ reported by ](https://www.law360.com/articles/1697183)Law360, that’s not what happened in the middle of a patent lawsuit between Impinj Inc. and NXP USA Inc. And Judge Gonzalez Rogers made it abundantly clear that nonsense would not fly in her courtroom or in her district:

“No lawyer should ever reach out to a law clerk of a judge during trial and suggest that at some point [the clerk] should contact him if he wants a job,” Judge Gonzalez Rogers said. “It is so inappropriate that it’s shocking to me that I have to say anything about this.”

Judge Gonzalez Rogers noted that during her sidebar discussions with the trial attorneys it “was suggested that this kind of thing happens in other jurisdictions.” The judge said she emailed other judges in the Northern District of California, as well as a friend who is a federal judge in Texas, and so far, the judges have unanimously replied to her that they have never heard of trial attorneys recruiting law clerks “in any case whatsoever.”

“In the Northern District of California, it is inappropriate, and it should never happen,” she said. “So I don’t know what people think is okay, but it is not.”

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Opposing counsel, Michael C. Hendershot of Jones Day, requested a mistrial in light of the inappropriate behavior. However, the judge denied that request.

Judge Gonzalez Rogers told defense counsel that although the lawyer’s conduct “was entirely inappropriate,” she pointed out that her clerk “has no impact” on what the jury will decide or how she instructs the jury, and “if anybody should be worried, it should be [Perkins Coie].”

“I’m not going to hold it against the company,” she added. “I’m not going to hold it against the client.”

Perkins Coie partner Ramsey M. Al-Salam was quick to fall on the sword over his colleague’s behavior.

“We apologize,” he said. “We regret it.”

He added, “If it helps, we could commit to not employ [the clerk],” and the promise would presumably eliminate any perception of favoritism.

Judge Gonzalez Rogers replied that the law clerk will not have any communication with the law firm, and she noted that the clerk doesn’t have any kind of job interview lined up with Perkins Coie.

“The answer right now is there is going to be zero communication with him,” she said.

Additionally the attorney at the center of the debacle will have to eat crow in front of their fellow attorneys at the firm:

The judge ordered the Perkins Coie lawyer to email all litigators at his firm by noon Sunday to explain what happened, and to tell his colleagues that the judge “said it was inappropriate, and it should not happen.” The judge also required the attorney to include her and opposing counsel as recipients on the email.

Let this be a lesson to all attorneys: knowing when *not* to recruit is as important as knowing when to recruit new attorneys.

# Summer Associate Offer Rates (2016): A Guide For Incoming Law Students
## If you're an incoming law student with dreams of a $180K Biglaw salary, this is a must-read.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onAugust 15, 2016 at 12:44 PMAugust 15, 2016 at 3:52 PM
5
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/summer-associate-offer-rates-2016-a-guide-for-incoming-law-students/&text=Summer%20Associate%20Offer%20Rates%20(2016):%20A%20Guide%20For%20Incoming%20Law%20Students)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/summer-associate-offer-rates-2016-a-guide-for-incoming-law-students/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/summer-associate-offer-rates-2016-a-guide-for-incoming-law-students/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Orientation for first-year students at law schools across the country begins next week, and most incoming students are dreaming about the $180K salaries they believe they’re sure to receive upon snagging a Biglaw job. Little do they know that only a select few of their classmates will be able to slip that brass ring upon their finger. For those of you who wish to keep the Biglaw fantasy alive, we’ve compiled a list of all of the law firms that have extended offers to 100 percent of their most recent summer associate classes.

How many first-year associates in large law firms across America will soon be cashing in on those extravagant $180K paychecks? If you’re an incoming law student, we’ve got some information that’ll help you answer that question.

Following up on last week’s post on [Biglaw offer rates](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/summer-associate-offer-rates-2016-tons-of-future-lawyers-will-be-making-180k/), here are more firms that have given offers to all of their summer associates (grouped by city and in alphabetical order):

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)

ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)

Congrats to everyone on their offers. Isn’t is awesome to have a job before graduation?

For those of you who are waiting to begin your third year of law school, if you have corrections to the list — i.e., an office listed above that does NOT belong on the 100 percent list — email us at [tips@abovethelaw.com](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=Summer%20Associate%20Offer%20Rate%20Correction), or text us at 646-820-8477.

If you have additions to this list, please note them in an [email to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=Summer%20Associate%20Offer%20Rates). Right now, it’s more newsworthy if a firm does NOT have a 100 percent offer rate than if it does.

On that note, please let us hear about firms that are NOT issuing offers to all their summer associates. If you know of a firm or an office with an unusually low offer rate — which we will arbitrarily define here as something under 66 percent, or two-thirds — please [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Offer%20Rate) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Offer Rate”). For example, we’ve heard some rumblings about a low offer rate at a certain firm’s Chicago office (a firm with a 100 percent offer rate in another city), as well as a low offer rate paired with cold offers at another firm’s Washington, D.C., office. If we hear more on this firm, or any others with low offer rates, we will investigate and perhaps write a story.

# Morning Docket: 06.13.18
## * Even the mainstream media is covering Biglaw's new salary scale, but dare we say, our coverage is much better. Check it out [here](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/2018-associate-salary-increase/) while you cross your fingers and pray that your firm follows the latest in associate compensation trends. [[New York Post](https://nypost.com/2018/06/12/starting-salary-for-law-school-grads-now-190k-at-national-firms/)] * "We don’t create or adjudicate under secret law or procedure." Former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe has filed suit against the Department of Justice, alleging that the DOJ has repeatedly refused to turn over any documents or identify any policy or procedures that were relied upon when firing him. [[Associated Press](https://apnews.com/7f1ef88e925e4a5c988d6686e1af2180)] * There's no vacancy on the Supreme Court right now, but Demand Justice, a liberal nonprofit group, has already spent a hefty sum on digital attack ads against some of the judges on President Trump's short list. Thus far, Judges Amy Coney Barrett of the Seventh Circuit, Brett Kavanaugh of the D.C. Circuit, and Amul Thapar of the Sixth Circuit have been treated to campaign coverage. [[BuzzFeed](https://www.buzzfeed.com/zoetillman/there-is-no-supreme-court-vacancy-but-this-group-is-already?utm_term=.gbXZA7XNo#.ehmNjO6Ye)] * In case you somehow missed it, over the government's antitrust objections, a federal judge has approved AT&T’s $85 billion acquisition of Time Warner following a six-week trial. They hope to close the deal by or before June 20. Have hope, everyone, maybe Time Warner Cable will actually function sometime soon. [[USA Today](https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2018/06/12/t-and-time-warner-deal-gets-green-light-more-m-could-follow/693873002/?csp=chromepush)] * The ABA's president has asked members of the House to oppose the part of the PROSPER Act that would end Public Service Loan Forgiveness, because "[w]ithout PSLF, the organizations that provide life- and livelihood-sustaining services will be even farther away from being able to meet these important challenges." Plus, many law school graduates wouldn't be able to survive. [[ABA Journal](http://www.abajournal.com/news/article/aba_asks_house_members_to_oppose_law_ending_public_service_loan_forgiveness)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 13, 2018 at 8:38 AMJune 12, 2018 at 10:17 PM
0

* In case you somehow missed it, over the government’s antitrust objections, a federal judge has approved AT&T’s $85 billion acquisition of Time Warner following a six-week trial. They hope to close the deal by or before June 20. Have hope, everyone, maybe Time Warner Cable will actually function sometime soon. [[USA Today](https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2018/06/12/t-and-time-warner-deal-gets-green-light-more-m-could-follow/693873002/?csp=chromepush)]

* The ABA’s president has asked members of the House to oppose the part of the PROSPER Act that would end Public Service Loan Forgiveness, because “[w]ithout PSLF, the organizations that provide life- and livelihood-sustaining services will be even farther away from being able to meet these important challenges.” Plus, many law school graduates wouldn’t be able to survive. # Former Trump Lawyer (Not One Of The Indicted Ones) On How The Former President's Latest Legal Strategy Could Backfire
## He's not impressed.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onAugust 16, 2023 at 4:16 PMAugust 16, 2023 at 3:30 PM
6
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/former-trump-lawyer-not-one-of-the-indicted-ones-on-how-the-former-presidents-latest-legal-strategy-could-backfire/&text=Former%20Trump%20Lawyer%20(Not%20One%20Of%20The%20Indicted%20Ones)%20On%20How%20The%20Former%20President’s%20Latest%20Legal%20Strategy%20Could%20Backfire)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/former-trump-lawyer-not-one-of-the-indicted-ones-on-how-the-former-presidents-latest-legal-strategy-could-backfire/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/former-trump-lawyer-not-one-of-the-indicted-ones-on-how-the-former-presidents-latest-legal-strategy-could-backfire/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Ty Cobb

[Ty Cobb](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/ty-cobb/), the former Hogan Lovells partner [who left Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/07/the-incredible-growing-presidential-legal-team/) to work ([briefly](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/ty-cobb-out-emmet-flood-in-constitutional-crisis-looms/)) in Trump’s White House, [continues](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/former-biglaw-partner-ty-cobb-shows-utter-contempt-for-trumps-proposed-defense/) to opine about his former boss’s legal troubles. As we all know, the[ fourth indictment](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/trump-lawyers-luck-finally-runs-out/) against Donald Trump came down this week, this one in Georgia over election fraud. (There’s also the New York case against him over [financial crimes](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/04/trump-indicted-for-34-felonies-its-not-the-payout-to-stormy-its-the-pay-up-to-cohen/) related to the Stormy Daniels hush money, the federal indictment over his[ handling of classified documents](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/judge-cannon-sets-trump-docs-case-for-may-trial-date/), and there’s the [federal case](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/third-donald-trump-indictement/) over that whole January 6th insurrection thing.)

As [is](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/04/donald-trumps-rant-against-judge-and-his-family-costs-his-support-on-fox-news/) [his](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/doj-says-trumps-rants-about-e-jean-carroll-were-not-part-of-his-job-trump-responds-with-further-ranting/) [wont](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/trump-baits-court-with-social-media-rants-about-jan-6-case/), Trump took to social media to complain about his latest legal headache. [This time](https://truthsocial.com/@realDonaldTrump/posts/110893712805150244), he boasted of a “major news conference” on Monday to present a “large, complex, detailed but irrefutable REPORT” on the 2020 election that will offer “a complete EXONERATION…Based on the results of this CONCLUSIVE Report, all charges should be dropped against me & others,” Trump wrote.

# 3 Practices To Get To A Balanced Legal Budget
## Please join us on [ February 25th](https://info.breakingmedia.com/3-practices-to-get-to-a-balanced-legal-budget) and learn how to effectively manage and optimize your legal budgets.
By [Above The Law and Axiom](https://info.breakingmedia.com/3-practices-to-get-to-a-balanced-legal-budget)  
onFebruary 18, 2021 at 12:16 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/3-practices-to-get-to-a-balanced-legal-budget/&text=3%20Practices%20To%20Get%20To%20A%20Balanced%20Legal%20Budget)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/3-practices-to-get-to-a-balanced-legal-budget/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/3-practices-to-get-to-a-balanced-legal-budget/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
As legal leaders grapple with contracting budgets, ambitious company-wide goals and initiatives, and seek to balance their in-house teams’ size and scope with the outside spend, effectively managing and optimizing their legal budgets is more important than ever.

On February 25th at 12 p.m. ET / 9 a.m. PT, join COO, Office of the General Counsel at AIG, Darren Guy, and former DGC & COO of Wells Fargo, Thomas Trujillo, as they explore how to:

- Collect the right data on the work of the in-house team to maximize cost savings;
- Drive efficiency through a balance of outside counsel spend, technology adoption, and alternative fee arrangement; and
- Manage new company and legal department initiatives with limited resources.
Speakers:
Darren R. Guy, COO, Office of the General Counsel, AIG
Thomas Trujillo, former EVP, DGC, COO, Wells Fargo Legal Department

Moderator:
Sara Morgan, SVP, Head of Global Talent, Axiom

By submitting the form below, you are opting in to receive communication from Above the Law and its partners.

# Footnotes Can Be Deadly
## Perhaps the biggest power of footnotes is that people often do not read them.
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onJanuary 18, 2023 at 5:17 PMJanuary 18, 2023 at 2:15 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/footnotes-can-be-deadly/&text=Footnotes%20Can%20Be%20Deadly)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/footnotes-can-be-deadly/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/footnotes-can-be-deadly/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
In law school, I had a constitutional law professor who mentioned on a few different occasions how footnotes can be deadly within the legal profession. The professor noted how footnote 4 of the Carolene Products case established an entire sphere of constitutional law, so even Supreme Court Justices could understand and harness the power of footnotes. From my own experience, there are a few ways how footnotes can be deadly in legal practice, and attorneys can use footnotes when attempting to accomplish certain tasks for their clients.

Perhaps the biggest power of footnotes is that people often do not read them. I was definitely guilty of this earlier in my career. Attorneys are busy people like all other kinds of professionals, and sometimes we take shortcuts when reviewing documents that we need to read in the course of our jobs. When skimming a document, an attorney might naturally not read the footnotes since footnotes presumably contain less important content than the body of a document. Moreover, I usually hate reading the papers of an adversary in the first place, and focusing on the body of a document is a solid way to save time.

One time, I filed a summary judgment motion against two parties. One of the parties only had a derivative claim, and this legally prevented her from bringing her claims in that case. In any event, my adversary never addressed the derivative claims of one of the parties in his papers. I had absolutely no idea why this lawyer did not address the derivative claims of one of the parties in his opposition papers. I thought this was all part of his strategy, and it was really distressing not to know why my adversary did not talk about some claims and focused on others.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
As it turned out, my adversary had dropped a footnote on the first page of his brief saying that he was fine with dismissing the case involving one of his clients and this was the reason why he was only focusing on the other party in his papers. Of course, normally a lawyer would sign a stipulation of discontinuance if he were fine dismissing the claims of a party, but agreeing to have summary judgment entered against a party also happened regularly. Had I just read this footnote, I would have saved myself a lot of heartache when preparing my reply papers. After this situation, I resolved that I would read each and every footnote contained in legal papers that I came across.

In many instances, footnotes can be a great way to include points in a brief without alerting your adversary to a weakness in your argument. Usually, parties need to mention arguments in front of a trial court if they wish to preserve arguments for appeal. As a result, lawyers may want to include points in their papers just in case they come up in future. In any event, it is possible that litigants can preserve arguments for appeal even if they only mention them in footnotes.

One time, I was drafting opposition papers in response to a nasty motion filed by an adversary. I discovered a damaging argument that my adversary could make against my position, but my adversary did not mention this argument in his moving papers. However, since I was unsure if my adversary would address this issue in his reply papers or if the court would decide to argue this point sua sponte, I wanted to touch upon this argument in my papers. However, I did not want to spend too much time on this argument since I did not want to alert my adversary to the fact that this argument existed.

As a result, I decided to touch upon this argument in the footnotes. The footnote was several sentences long, so I was worried that it would not stay under the radar and that my adversary would be tipped off that this damaging argument against my position existed. I was dreading my adversary filing reply papers, but when I finally reviewed the reply papers, I was relieved to discover that my adversary did not discuss the argument I feared. I think there was a good chance that my adversary never read my footnote or at least did not understand the potential argument that could have been made against me.

In any event, footnotes can be extremely useful to attorneys, and they can be deadly if lawyers do not take the time to read footnotes. Accordingly, lawyers should gloss over footnotes at their own peril.

# Am Law 100 Released -- A Lot Of Firms Made A Lot Of Money
## Which firms delivered the highest profits per partner this year?
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onApril 24, 2018 at 11:40 AMApril 24, 2018 at 11:40 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/am-law-100-released-a-lot-of-firms-made-a-lot-of-money/&text=Am%20Law%20100%20Released%20—%20A%20Lot%20Of%20Firms%20Made%20A%20Lot%20Of%20Money)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/am-law-100-released-a-lot-of-firms-made-a-lot-of-money/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/am-law-100-released-a-lot-of-firms-made-a-lot-of-money/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The Am Law 100 are now live and you can check out the [annual industry scoreboard in full](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/04/24/the-2018-am-law-100/) over at American Lawyer. But for those of you who just can’t wait to get a sneak peek at the top performers across the major categories in the Am Law rankings, we’ve got your back. We’ll have more detailed discussion over the next few days as we dig in and pick apart these numbers.

But we already know for sure that the [elite firms pulled even farther away](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/am-law-100-news-elite-new-york-dominate-in-profits-and-revenue/) from the rest of the industry.

Let’s check out some stats.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Profits Per Equity Partner

The long-accepted gold standard of Biglaw success has [taken some hits as a valuable metric](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/02/will-ppp-be-dethroned/) in recent years, but we’re still going to salivate like dogs over this list, so why not revel in it. Here are the top 5 firms in PPP (or PPEP as the case may be). The whole list is [available here](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/04/24/the-2018-am-law-100-ranked-by-profits-per-equity-partner/):

1. Wachtell
2. Quinn Emanuel
3. Kirkland
4. Paul Weiss
5. Sullivan & Cromwell

Gross Revenue

Which law firms are raking in the most cash overall? As one might expect, the biggest of the big firms. The globalist of the global firms. The vereinist of the verein firms. All right, that didn’t quite work, but here are the top dogs in revenue. A whopping 31 firms crested $1 billion in revenue this year. The [full list is here](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/04/24/the-2018-am-law-100-ranked-by-gross-revenue/):

1. Kirkland
2. Latham
3. Baker McKenzie (verein)
4. DLA (verein)
5. Skadden

Revenue Per Lawyer

While profits per partner falls out of vogue as the prime indicator of firm health, people have turned to revenue per lawyer, preferring to judge the strength of a firm based on how much cash they’ve managed to squeeze out of every attorney on the payroll. [Full list here](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/04/24/the-2018-am-law-100-ranked-by-revenue-per-lawyer/):

1. Wachtell
2. Sullivan & Cromwell
3. Quinn Emanuel
4. Kirkland
5. Skadden

Compensation Per Partner

Finally, let’s do a little Lifestyles of the Rich and Rainmaking by checking out compensation per partner. What partners managed to take home the biggest scores this year? Well… obviously Wachtell, but who else. [Full list is here](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/04/24/the-2018-am-law-100-ranked-by-compensation-all-partners/):

1. Wachtell
2. Paul Weiss
3. Sullivan & Cromwell
4. Cravath
5. Davis Polk

Check out the complete coverage from American Lawyer including the full stats, as well as some other categories not previewed above, and a bevy of articles providing deeper analysis. And stay tuned to Above the Law for more coverage over the coming days.

# Stats Of The Week: New Global M&A Law Firm Leaders
## Despite a geopolitically tumultuous 2016, the U.S. M&A market had a robust year.
By [Brian Dalton](https://abovethelaw.com/author/brian-dalton/)  
onJanuary 27, 2017 at 5:16 PMJanuary 28, 2017 at 10:56 PM
23
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/01/stats-of-the-week-new-global-ma-law-firm-leaders/&text=Stats%20Of%20The%20Week:%20New%20Global%20M&A%20Law%20Firm%20Leaders)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/01/stats-of-the-week-new-global-ma-law-firm-leaders/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/01/stats-of-the-week-new-global-ma-law-firm-leaders/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

[Mergermarket ](http://www.mergermarket.com/info/)has released its Global M&A roundup for last year, including its league tables for legal advisors, and there has been a significant reshuffling at the top. Despite a geopolitically tumultuous 2016, the U.S. M&A market had a robust year, with about $1.5 trillion in deals, the second-highest value since Mergermarket starting keeping track in 2001.

[White & Case](https://abovethelaw.com/law-firms/white-case-llp/?utm_source=law_firm_directory&utm_medium=search_result&utm_campaign=cc_redesign) vaulted to the No. 1 position in the 2016 league tables in deal value, moving up from ninth place in 2015. [Sullivan & Cromwell](https://abovethelaw.com/law-firms/sullivan-cromwell-llp/?utm_source=law_firm_directory&utm_medium=search_result&utm_campaign=cc_redesign) moved from fifth place to second place, and [Davis Polk & Wardwell](https://abovethelaw.com/law-firms/davis-polk/?utm_source=law_firm_directory&utm_medium=search_result&utm_campaign=cc_redesign) made a big jump from tenth to third place.

Check out the [full report here](http://www.mergermarket.com/pdf/MergermarketLegalLeagueTableReport.Q42016.pdf).

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)

Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
(Note that the Mergermarket rankings do not distinguish between advising a principal versus participating in some other, much smaller role, such as advising a bank on some minor part of the transaction. This has been the subject of [complaints within the M&A bar](https://bol.bna.com/the-real-list-of-top-ma-law-firms-in-2016/).)

[Brian Dalton](https://abovethelaw.com/author/brian-dalton/) is the director of research for Breaking Media. Feel free to [email him](mailto:brian@breakingmedia.com) with any questions or comments.

# Yes, Even Biglaw Partners Stare Into The Abyss Sometimes
## Who ever said work/life balance was going to be easy?
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 19, 2017 at 1:01 PM
15
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/12/yes-even-biglaw-partners-stare-into-the-abyss-sometimes/&text=Yes,%20Even%20Biglaw%20Partners%20Stare%20Into%20The%20Abyss%20Sometimes)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/12/yes-even-biglaw-partners-stare-into-the-abyss-sometimes/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/12/yes-even-biglaw-partners-stare-into-the-abyss-sometimes/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
No one ever said balancing a high-powered legal career at a Biglaw firm with an actual personal life was going to be easy. The challenges are only magnified if you are responsible for the health and well-being of three tiny humans.

Capturing the universality of this struggle is the beauty of the CorporetteMoms series “Week in the Life of a Working Mom.” [This week’s offering](http://corporettemoms.com/biglaw-partner-work-life-balance/) is the experience of a Biglaw litigation partner (“R”) in the Midwest who has three kids — twin 9 year olds and a 3 year old. And to be honest, for most of the week R seems to be cruising. Sure, it’s stressful and there are a lot of things to be done, but R’s hours seem… dare I say it, reasonable — she is even able to make time to attend her kids’ extracurriculars.

Things are going along just swimmingly until Thursday. That’s when a stomach bug hits the toddler and you just know mom’s day is going to be a wreck. It’s oddly comforting knowing the work of a partner suffers when their home life is in upheaval. Just check out how productive R was that day:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
6:30 a.m. Alarm goes off. Was I asleep? Who knows. Even my dreams are of vomit and exhaustion. I was supposed to get up at 5:00 and go to the gym for strength training, but that ship sailed around the fourth vomiting episode at 4:00 a.m. (Really, it sailed with the first, but who’s counting?) Husband and I engage in brief negotiation about whether we can take shifts. He has a proposal to get out and wants me to stay home in the morning. I have a 9:30 call and a 2:00 meeting, so I offer late afternoon. As usual, my job wins. I always try to stay home when I can, because it’s rare that I can. But I’m 4/5 of our household income, so this is a choice we both agree with.
7:45 a.m. I leave for work. Husband will get the older kids on the bus as usual and stay home with the youngest. I stop for the biggest coffee Dunkin’ Donuts sells, and two donuts, because I’ve given up hope for the day.
8:30 a.m. Arrive at work. Drink coffee and stare into the abyss like a zombie. Try to prepare for 9:30 call.
9:30 a.m.–10:30 a.m. Call.
10:30 a.m.–11:30 a.m. Stare into the abyss.
11:30 a.m. Go with coworker to grab Subway, which I eat at my desk while staring into the abyss.
2:00 p.m.–3:00 p.m. Attend a webinar.
3:00 p.m. Leave office. My husband has figured out his proposal, but the youngest is still sick and can’t leave the house, so I’m on evening extracurricular duty.
3:45 p.m. Arrive home and assess pitiful situation on the sick child front.
4:15 p.m. Pick up son from bus, take him home to get ready for soccer.
5:00 p.m. Pick up older daughter from after-school STEM program.
5:30 p.m.–6:30 p.m. Soccer practice; sit in chair and watch practice while daughter reads book.
6:30 p.m.–7:00 p.m Drive home; talk to kids about school.
7:00 p.m. Eat dinner while husband puts pitiful youngest to bed.
7:30 p.m. Head to family room where husband and kids play video games. My brain is mush, so I just watch them and play games on my phone.

See, Biglaw partners — they’re just like us.

Kathryn Rubino is an editor at Above the Law. AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](https://twitter.com/Kathryn1)).

# Holdout Firm Flip-Flops On Salary
## After all that, they offer raises anyway.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJuly 8, 2016 at 5:31 PMJuly 8, 2016 at 5:04 PM
43
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/07/holdout-firm-flip-flops-on-salary/&text=Holdout%20Firm%20Flip-Flops%20On%20Salary)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/07/holdout-firm-flip-flops-on-salary/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/07/holdout-firm-flip-flops-on-salary/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Seyfarth Shaw got a lot of flak when it boldly tried to put a stop to the salary frenzy. The firm [blew off the idea of raises](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/one-firm-decides-to-pump-the-brakes-on-this-whole-raise-thing/), and its chairman emeritus penned an article proclaiming woe to firms that raise their salaries in the vain hope that this could halt the gathering “compensamentum.” Even at the time, this felt like a Biglaw Wile E. Coyote lofting a miniature umbrella to shield it from the anvil.

And so today, Seyfarth Shaw joins the [Covington Memorial Salary Flip-Flop Club](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/biglaw-firm-changes-course-on-associate-compensation/) with a salary increase announcement.

First of all, raises are effective on October 1, fully three months after most associates got their raises. Is the third quarter that tight?

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Second, different Seyfarth offices are on different scales, which [actually makes sense](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/heres-why-you-dont-deserve-the-same-raise-in-pictures/). But how much each office gets may cause some grumbling.

We don’t have the precise New York office scale at this time, but we’ve been told that it runs from $180K to $300K — whether that matches the Cravath scale through the seventh year or is the result of some crunching at the senior end remains to be seen.

We’ve heard that the bulk of Seyfarth’s other domestic offices (with the possible exception of outliers like Atlanta or Sacramento) will be on a $160K to $280K scale. [This memo from San Francisco](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/07/holdout-firm-flip-flops-on-salary/2/) details that scale. Seyfarth employs one of those funky 3×3 compensation grids, but for the sake of simplicity this is what it looks like converted into traditional classes:

First-year	$165K
Second-year	$175K
Third-year	$185K
Fourth-year	$205K
Fifth-year	$225K
Sixth-year	$240K
Seventh-year	$260K
Eighth-year	$270K
Ninth-year	$280K

The bad news: it’s not matching Cravath. The good news: most years are getting as big or bigger raises from their current salary. Seyfarth was already below the $160K market in San Francisco, and this raise may not match Cravath but draws closer. No Cravath raise exceeded $35K per year, while a couple of the more senior Seyfarth classes on this scale are receiving $40K bumps over their current salary. That’s not nothing.

One tipster notes:

They also hinted at changes to bonuses and leave policies. Honestly, better than I thought it would be. No change in hours requirements. I think they’re treating Boston as a regional office, which makes no sense to me because we’re one of the most profitable offices….
¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Double points for the emoticon.

Then there’s the really bad news — if you’re an income partner, that is. According to at least one source, some of these raises place senior associates above income partners! Needless to say, those lawyers aren’t pleased.

So a muted congratulations to Seyfarth Shaw associates. This may not be all you could have hoped for, but it’s certainly much more than it looked like you’d get a couple weeks ago.

# The 'Allen & O'Melvery' Merger Seems To Be Gaining Steam
## There may be some internal opposition... but it doesn't look like it's going to stop this.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onOctober 29, 2018 at 10:55 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/the-allen-omelvery-merger-seems-to-be-gaining-steam/&text=The%20‘Allen%20&%20O’Melvery’%20Merger%20Seems%20To%20Be%20Gaining%20Steam)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/the-allen-omelvery-merger-seems-to-be-gaining-steam/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/the-allen-omelvery-merger-seems-to-be-gaining-steam/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Nothing like a good global law firm merger to get the blood flowing on a Monday morning. The [ongoing saga of the Allen & Overy and O’Melveny & Myers](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/checking-in-on-allen-omelvery-biglaws-most-hilarious-will-they-or-wont-they-romcom/) popped up again amid reports of more interfirm partner meetups to curry global interest in the deal.

It looks like it’s only a matter of time before this one gets done. The PPP gap between the two firms — a common cause of scuttled deals — is virtually non-existent and both sides see practice complements across the world. Deals this good don’t usually die on the vine.

ALM’s International reports the pro-merger forces have been on a whistlestop tour, meeting in Germany, London, Singapore, and, naturally, at the firm’s annual meeting in Miami. And it appears all this work is starting to pay off, with the mood “inching towards a merger” a former A&O partner told International.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
“The A&O litigators, especially in the U.S., desperately want to have it. They’ve never had a strong brand in the U.S. and this gives them a way.”

However, one current A&O partner argued it might not be a “slam dunk.”

“It is a numbers vote—but even if you have 500 partners in favor and 50 corporate partners in London against it, you’d be a brave person to put it to a vote,” they said.

Maybe. But if those 50 partners really cared enough to bolt from a newly merged firm, one might expect them to be doing more right now than bitching behind the scenes. That same former partner cited above describes the London scene as a bunch of complainers who lack any drive to mount a formal challenge against the mounting merger talk.

This is the “speak now or forever hold your peace” point in the wedding ceremony and these London corporate types seem satisfied to comfortably kvetch about it at the reception.

[Allen & Overy, O’Melveny Partners Meet as Merger Moves Closer](https://www.law.com/2018/10/26/allen-overy-and-omelveny-partners-meet-as-merger-inches-closer-396-8484/) [International]

# Biglaw Firms Want Associates To Return To The Office -- So They're Offering Remote Summer Work
## It's a plan that makes lawyers wonder why they need to go back to the office at all.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 29, 2022 at 5:47 PMJune 29, 2022 at 2:17 PM
13
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/biglaw-firms-want-associates-to-return-to-the-office-so-theyre-offering-remote-summer-work/&text=Biglaw%20Firms%20Want%20Associates%20To%20Return%20To%20The%20Office%20—%20So%20They’re%20Offering%20Remote%20Summer%20Work)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/biglaw-firms-want-associates-to-return-to-the-office-so-theyre-offering-remote-summer-work/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/biglaw-firms-want-associates-to-return-to-the-office-so-theyre-offering-remote-summer-work/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
If they can effectively do their jobs remotely for the past several years, and now for the month of August, what is the argument for being in the office long term? That’s the question on people’s minds when firms take this approach or have strict in-office expectations generally.

— Jessica Cox, a senior executive search associate at Calibrate Legal, commenting during an interview with the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2022/06/29/as-new-york-law-firms-turn-to-remote-august-questions-linger-on-industrys-long-term-office-flexibility/) on Biglaw firms’ plans for remote summer work while at the same time demanding that associates return to the office. More than two years into the pandemic, associates are wondering why the flexibility needs to end.

# Will Associate Raises Lead To An Exodus From New York?
## Everywhere to $180K has a lot of repercussions.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJune 21, 2016 at 1:32 PM
0
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/will-associate-raises-lead-to-an-exodus-from-new-york/&text=Will%20Associate%20Raises%20Lead%20To%20An%20Exodus%20From%20New%20York?)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/will-associate-raises-lead-to-an-exodus-from-new-york/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/will-associate-raises-lead-to-an-exodus-from-new-york/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
I do expect a continued uptick in relocations out of New York City. This was already a trend before [the raises] happened, but I think it will accelerate the trend.

—[Michael Jude Di Gennaro](http://laterallink.com/about/team/109), senior director at [Lateral Link](http://laterallink.com/), [explaining why](http://www.law360.com/articles/808166) the #Everywhereto180 trend [Biglaw firms increasing salaries to the $180,000 scale in all their U.S. offices] is probably going to cause a lot of people to look for jobs in [less expensive markets](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/stats-of-the-week-san-antonio-to-462k/) where they can [still pull down MoneyLaw salaries](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/no-your-office-doesnt-deserve-the-ny-to-180-raise/).

# Picking Up The Tab For Donald Trump's Ballooning Legal Bills
## What's $40 million between friends?
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJuly 31, 2023 at 12:43 PMJuly 31, 2023 at 12:38 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/picking-up-the-tab-for-donald-trumps-ballooning-legal-bills/&text=Picking%20Up%20The%20Tab%20For%20Donald%20Trump’s%20Ballooning%20Legal%20Bills)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/picking-up-the-tab-for-donald-trumps-ballooning-legal-bills/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/picking-up-the-tab-for-donald-trumps-ballooning-legal-bills/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Photo by PAUL J. RICHARDS/AFP/Getty Images)

This is what happens when there are two indictments against you, and everyone [basically expects a third](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/biglaw-partner-neal-katyal-sounds-off-on-when-we-can-expect-that-third-donald-trump-indictment/) (and maybe a [fourth](https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2023/07/11/trump-grand-jury-fulton-county-georgia/?itid=lk_inline_manual_5)). You have to hire lawyers and they have to get paid.

According to [reports](https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/2023/07/29/trump-lawyers-pac-deoliveira-loyal/), the Donald Trump-founded political action committee (PAC), Save America, spent $40.2 million on legal bills in the first half of 2023. That means the PAC has spent $56 million since Trump left office. In fact, legal bills are the number one expense for the PAC in Trump’s 2024 presidential run. It’s basically turned into a bizarro litigation financier with no chance of any upside.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
But it isn’t only the former president’s bills getting picked up. Others in his orbit being drawn into the legal fray are also getting their bills paid.

In an indictment unsealed Thursday charging Trump, his longtime valet Waltine “Walt” Nauta, and his property manager Carlos De Oliveira in the classified documents case, authorities allege that Trump called De Oliveira last August to say he would pay for De Oliveira’s attorney. That same day, authorities said, Nauta had a conversation with a different Trump employee who assured Nauta that De Oliveira was loyal to Trump.

Lawyers for De Oliveira and Nauta declined to comment, as did a spokesman for special counsel Jack Smith, who is leading the federal investigations of Trump.

Not that the spending is necessarily a problem (legally) according to campaign finance expert Paul Seamus Ryan. “It’s an extraordinary sum of money,” he said. “At the end of the day it’s up to the donors to decide if that’s the way they want their money spent. My sense is if you’re giving money to Trump in 2023, you’re fine with it.”

And like the Earth’s average temperature, these numbers are expected to disturbingly rise.

# Morning Docket: 05.04.18
## * Mueller requests 70 blank subpoenas! Which... actually doesn't seem like an inordinate amount in a case like Manafort's, but let's overreact anyway. [[Courthouse News Service](https://www.courthousenews.com/mueller-seeks-70-blank-subpoenas-in-manafort-case/)] * Ty Cobb absolutely demolishes Steve Bannon. [[Vanity Fair](https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2018/05/ty-cobb-knifes-steve-bannon-on-his-way-out-the-door)] * Trump Place successfully won the right to drop Trump's name from the building. According to the Constitution, the building will now be called "Pence Place." [[New York Times](https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/03/nyregion/trump-place-name-nyc.html)] * Wild lawsuit against the former president of Ohio Christian University, who allegedly pulled a Trump and fired the people investigating wrongdoing. That move seems to be coming back to haunt him. [[Inside Higher Ed](https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2018/05/03/lawsuit-charges-university-fired-its-lawyer-investigating-allegations-misconduct)] * Young lawyers call for office overhaul. Ostensibly this is to make offices better suited to modern work styles, but it's mostly because law offices are generally all terrible and we're reaching for any excuse that might actually convince someone to renovate. [[Law.com](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/05/03/young-lawyers-call-for-revamping-of-law-firm-offices-to-meet-new-industry-needs/)] * Firm plans IPO to raise $58 million. [[International](https://www.law.com/2018/05/03/rosenblatt-seeks-to-raise-43m-in-fourth-ever-law-firm-ipo-396-3077/)] * A copy of an intangible thing can be tangible rules NY Court of Appeals after, apparently, binging on edibles [[Law 360](https://www.law360.com/newyork/articles/1040004/ny-high-court-affirms-goldman-code-swiper-s-conviction)]
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onMay 4, 2018 at 8:48 AM
1

# Elite Biglaw Firm Joins Top Dollar Scale For Associate Salaries (And Opens A New Office To Boot)
## The momentum continues with raises for associates across the country.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 18, 2018 at 12:56 PMJune 18, 2018 at 1:48 PM
5
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/elite-biglaw-firm-joins-top-dollar-scale-for-associate-salaries-and-opens-a-new-office-to-boot/&text=Elite%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Joins%20Top%20Dollar%20Scale%20For%20Associate%20Salaries%20(And%20Opens%20A%20New%20Office%20To%20Boot))[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/elite-biglaw-firm-joins-top-dollar-scale-for-associate-salaries-and-opens-a-new-office-to-boot/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/elite-biglaw-firm-joins-top-dollar-scale-for-associate-salaries-and-opens-a-new-office-to-boot/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
As the market seems to be coalescing around a modest salary increase to cover cost of living increases since the Great Associate Cash Fest of 2016 and a tidy summer bonus, the clock’s been ticking on the Am Law Elite to fall into line. It took a whole week for Cravath to embrace the raise Milbank launched upon the world, and another three days after that for Kirkland to concede that the market had truly shifted.

But now that we’re seeing some clarity out there, it’s time for the rest of the top firms to join the festivities, and White & Case has stepped up to the plate. The firm will be matching the prevailing market salaries all the way up the scale (and down the scale… to provide summers a corresponding bump) and providing the summer bonuses that have become standard.

While the memo is addressed to “US Associates & Counsel” there may be some domestic associates left out. After announcing that the firm is “increasing salaries and awarding summer bonuses to US associates in good standing,” it notes that US offices “not on the New York base salary scale” will have raises determined by their offices and passed along on an individual basis. Back in 2016, this language meant that White & Case’s Miami office got left out. But those associates will be seeing a raise of their own, even if it doesn’t match the NY scale.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
(UPDATE: FYI, the Miami Scale is included on the next page as well)

Speaking of offices — [and aren’t we always talking about offices](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/06/white-case-has-built-the-new-modern-law-firm-office-and-its-awesome/) — White & Case’s announcement should generate some interest in the Chicago market as well, where the firm announced earlier today that it would be opening a new outpost. The office will be headed up by White & Case partner Jason Zakia, who will relocate from Miami to take on the role, joined by private equity lawyer Gary Silverman, joining White & Case from Greenberg Traurig, and white-collar attorney Carolyn Gurland, who previously ran her own shop. This is the second new office for White & Case this year, having opened in Houston in February.

Congratulations to White & Case associates.

As always, this is the point where we remind all of you that we depend on your tips to stay on top of this stuff. So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Raises%20Salaries) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Raises Salaries”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

# Trump's Transgender Ban Is Bait, It's Not A Reality... Yet
## Trump can make the military bigoted, but he has to actually make them.
By [Elie Mystal](https://abovethelaw.com/author/elie-mystal/)  
onJuly 26, 2017 at 12:49 PMJuly 26, 2017 at 4:18 PM
461
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/07/trumps-transgender-ban-is-bait-its-not-a-law-yet/&text=Trump’s%20Transgender%20Ban%20Is%20Bait,%20It’s%20Not%20A%20Reality…%20Yet)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/07/trumps-transgender-ban-is-bait-its-not-a-law-yet/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/07/trumps-transgender-ban-is-bait-its-not-a-law-yet/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

When are these colonies gonna rise up? (Photo Getty)

Donald Trump did not ban transgender individuals from serving in “any capacity in the U.S. military.” [I know he just said so on Twitter](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/26/us/politics/trump-transgender-military.html). But a tweet is not an executive order. A tweet is not a law and, goddamnit, we are still a nation of laws.

As laws go, the president’s clear intention to deny equal protection to transgender individuals should make it even more difficult for him to implement his tweet as official U.S. policy. Trump just told us where he intends to attack next, without being ready to actually attack. WHICH IS DUMB. We now have what Sun-Tzu would call “foreknowledge” of our enemy’s plans. We can mount a defense and defeat him.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Trump can, absolutely, do this. But he hasn’t done it yet. The response from the Pentagon is instructive here. [From USAToday](https://www.usnews.com/news/politics/articles/2017-07-26/the-latest-pentagon-not-aware-of-trump-transgender-decision):

A Pentagon spokesman, Navy Capt. Jeff Davis, said in a brief written statement that the Pentagon is working with the White House to “address” what he calls “the new guidance” from the president on transgender individuals serving in the military.

Davis said the Pentagon will provide revised guidance to Defense Department officials “in the near future.”

That’s military-speak for “I have no idea what the old man is talking about, but I’m not ready to lead a junta, so we’ll get back to you.”

The devil’s in the “revised guidance.” The military has been proceeding along the lines that transgender people are allowed to serve openly. Last month the House [defeated a proposal](http://www.cnn.com/2017/07/13/politics/house-defeats-bid-block-pentagon-transgender-surgeries/index.html), with the help of 24 Republicans even, to deny Pentagon resources for gender reassignment surgery. This issue has been fought and decided. Trump cannot just roll all of that back ON TWITTER. The Pentagon is going to have to translate the president’s bigoted ravings into workable guidance that the ginormous U.S. Armed Services can implement as policy. And then that policy will be looked at in Congress and, likely, litigated in the courts.

“Smear the Queer” is a command the “Commander-in-Chief” can utter, but he can’t do it like he’s telling his orc-humpers to defend a position in a Warhammer video game. How will the military determine transgender status? Who gets to ask? Who has to tell? What about all the transgender people who came out because Obama and Ash Carter said it was okay? Do they get honorable discharges? What about pensions? WHO KNEW DISCRIMINATING AGAINST TRANSGENDER INDIVIDUALS COULD BE SO COMPLICATED?

Trump’s tweets would not stop f**king MULAN from serving.

These tweets are for idiots. Trump’s supporters are literally too stupid to think through the first contact this ban would have with reality. But they know they hate “women” who still have “a penis” and so anything that sounds like it might make their lives more difficult gives them comfort while they feast on mayonnaise sandwiches and piss beer.

An oft-cited RAND Corporation study suggests that there are 2,450 active transgender service members, in our 1.3 million-member military. I struggle to conceive of how pathetic you have to be to CARE about the genital disposition of less than 1% of the men and women who are fighting for your oil. Trump people are literally the worst.

But “progressives” are easily distracted. Republicans are flying back from taxpayer-provided brain surgery to take health care away from taxpayers. Trump is trying to fire an independent investigator for investigating independently. The “beleaguered” Attorney General is trying to make cities more vulnerable to terrorist attacks if they aren’t racist enough. This entire administration is a disaster.

Smacking around transgender individuals on Twitter without bothering to issue new actionable policy is like throwing some Christians to the lions to keep the mob on your side and the nobles suitably cowed. It’s an old trick.

Transgender people are being used as bait. That’s probably the most disgusting part of Trump’s tweetstorm. Trump isn’t even giving the transgender community the dignity of their destruction being his ultimate objective. He’s just using their lives as a means to his ends.

[Trump Says That Transgender People Will Not Be Allowed in the Military](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/26/us/politics/trump-transgender-military.html) [New York Times]

Elie Mystal is an editor of Above the Law and the Legal Editor for [More Perfect](http://www.wnyc.org/shows/radiolabmoreperfect). He can be reached [@ElieNYC](https://twitter.com/ElieNYC?lang=en) on Twitter, or at [elie@abovethelaw.com](mailto:elie@abovethelaw.com). He will resist.

# This Firm Shows Associates The Best Way To Kick Off A Holiday Weekend — With Raises!
## Now that’s a creative way to help associates celebrate.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onSeptember 7, 2021 at 11:12 AMOctober 21, 2021 at 1:03 PM
7
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/09/morris-nichols-raise-2021/&text=This%20Firm%20Shows%20Associates%20The%20Best%20Way%20To%20Kick%20Off%20A%20Holiday%20Weekend%20—%20With%20Raises!)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/09/morris-nichols-raise-2021/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/09/morris-nichols-raise-2021/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It’s been about a month since the last time a law firm announced anything other than an office reopening plan or a vaccine mandate, but it looks like some firms are still interested in announcing big money moves. And what better time to let associates know that they’re about to get a huge cash influx than before a long holiday weekend?

On Friday, Morris Nichols Arsht & Tunnell, a Delaware firm rated as one of the [best in the Mid-Atlantic region](https://www.vault.com/company-profiles/law/morris-nichols-arsht-tunnell) by Vault, announced that it would be increasing salaries for first-year attorneys, effective immediately. Entry-level associates at the firm will now be making $190,000, up $15,000 from the $175,000 they’d been making previously.

According to a [press release](https://www.morrisnichols.com/news-morris-nichols-increases-associate-salaries-to-190), Morris Nichols is a firm that prides itself on its “deep pool of talented attorneys and holds great appreciation for their dedication,” so while nothing is specifically mentioned about salary increases for all other associates, we imagine they must be seeing commensurate raises as well.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
So, why did the firm finally decide to raise salaries? Because like all other firms, Morris Nichols wants to take advantage of the hot lateral market. From the firm’s press release:

Hiring top associate candidates is a key component of the firm’s ongoing vitality and future success as a Delaware market leader. To continue to attract top attorneys, Morris Nichols will increase starting associate salaries….

Better late than never!

This first-year salary bump may not be match the Davis Polk money that’s become the prevailing rate in more major markets ($202.5K for the Class of 2021 and $205K for the Class of 2020, to be specific), but more money is more money, so congratulations to all associates at the firm.

Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

# Am Law 100 Firm Offers 200% Profit-Sharing Bonus To Some Of Its Hardest Workers
## Congratulations to all!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJanuary 25, 2021 at 12:49 PMJanuary 25, 2021 at 1:14 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/01/am-law-100-firm-offers-200-profit-sharing-bonus-to-some-of-its-hardest-workers/&text=Am%20Law%20100%20Firm%20Offers%20200%%20Profit-Sharing%20Bonus%20To%20Some%20Of%20Its%20Hardest%20Workers)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/01/am-law-100-firm-offers-200-profit-sharing-bonus-to-some-of-its-hardest-workers/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/01/am-law-100-firm-offers-200-profit-sharing-bonus-to-some-of-its-hardest-workers/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ever since Biglaw bonus season started, we’ve received a slew of emails from law firm support staff wondering what their fate may be as money continues to rain down upon associates. 2020 was an incredibly difficult year for everyone, and it remains important to remember that Biglaw is not made of attorneys alone. After all, it takes an army for law firms this large to run, and the behind-the-scenes battalions of staff members deserve their due, too. That said, many firms have gone out of their way to show their support staff that they truly matter.

The latest firm to dip into their pockets to say thank you to staff is Sheppard Mullin. Last week, on the same day the firm offered [special bonuses to associates](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/01/am-law-100-firm-finally-decides-to-offer-special-bonuses-to-associates/), staff members were notified that they, too, would be receiving special bonuses. Here’s an excerpt from a memo sent by Ted Tinson, the firm’s chief operating officer:

At the end of the day, while a challenging year in so many ways, 2020 turned out to be a successful financial year for the firm. The Executive Committee, Partners, and I would like to thank you for all of your efforts. One way we do this each year is through our profit sharing bonus. In each of our last two years – also successful years – we have paid at 150% of our target bonus level. For 2020, the Executive Committee has approved a payment of 200% of our target profit sharing level. Each of you who are eligible will be receiving a bonus of two weeks’ salary. We will make that payment in the paycheck of February 5th.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Congratulations to all eligible staff members at the firm!

(Flip to the next page to read the full Sheppard Mullin memo.)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for all of your help!
